question: What information is considered 'addition' when registering a document?
answer: Section 2(1) of the Registration Act, 1908 defines 'addition' as the person's place of residence, profession, trade, rank, title (if any), and their father's name or mother's name if they are usually described as the son/daughter of their mother.  Essentially, it's the details used to identify the person being registered.
law_reference: The Registration Act, 1908, Part I, Section 2
input_context:
2. In this Act, unless there is anything repugnant in the subject or context,
 
 
(1) “addition” means the place of residence, and the profession, trade, rank and title (if any) of a person described, and his father's name, or where he is usually described as the son of his mother, then his mother's name:
 
 
(2) “book” includes a portion of a book and also any number of sheets connected together with a view of forming a book or portion of a book:
 
 
(2a) “co-operative society” means a co-operative society registered under the Co-operative Societies Act, 1912, or under any other law for the time being in force relating to the registration of co-operative societies.
 
 
(3) “district” and “sub-district” respectively mean a district and sub-district formed under this Act:
 
 
(4) “District Court” includes the High Court Division in its ordinary original civil jurisdiction:
 
 
(5) “endorsement” and “endorsed” include and apply to an entry in writing by a registering officer on a rider or covering slip to any document tendered for registration under this Act:
 
 
(6) “immoveable property” includes land, buildings, benefits to arise out of land and things attached to the earth, or permanently fastened to anything attached to the earth, hereditary allowances, rights to ways, lights, ferries and fisheries but does not include
 
 
(a) standing timber, growing crops or grass whether immediate severance thereof it intended or not;
 
 
(b) fruit upon and juice in trees whether in existence or to grow in future; and
 
 
(c) machinery embedded in or attached to the earth, when dealt with apart from the land:
 
 
(7) “lease” includes a counter-part, kabuliyat and an undertaking to cultivate or occupy:
 
 
(8) “minor” means a person who, according to the personal law to which he is subject, has not attained majority:
 
 
(9) “moveable property” means property of every description, except immoveable property:
 
 
(10) “representative” includes the guardian of a minor and the committee or other legal curator of a lunatic or idiot: and
 
 
(11) “tout' means a person
 
 
(a) who habitually frequents the precincts of a registration office, without a licence granted to him under the rules made under section 80G, for the purpose of obtaining employment for himself or for any other person in connection with any registration business; or
 
 
(b) who is declared to be deemed to be a tout for the purposes of this Act by rules made under section 80G;

question: Does the definition of 'book' only refer to traditional bound books?
answer: Section 2(2) of the Registration Act, 1908 clarifies that 'book' isn't just a bound book. It also includes any portion of a book or even multiple sheets connected together intending to form a book or part of a book. So, a collection of loose pages intended as a record is also considered a book for registration purposes.

question: আমি একজন দলিল নিবন্ধনের জন্য ‘tout’ এর সংজ্ঞা কী?

question: Who is the Inspector-General of Registration for Bangladesh, and how is this person chosen?
answer: The government is responsible for appointing an officer to be the Inspector-General of Registration for Bangladesh (Section 3). However, the government also has the power to delegate this role – they can direct that the responsibilities of the Inspector-General are handled by other officers, possibly within specific areas, instead of directly appointing someone to that title. So, it's not always a direct appointment.
law_reference: The Registration Act, 1908, Part II, Section 3
input_context:
3. (1) The Government shall appoint an officer to be the Inspector-General of Registration for Bangladesh:
 
 
Provided that the Government may, instead of making such appointment, direct that all or any of the powers and duties hereinafter conferred and imposed upon the Inspector-General shall be exercised and performed by such officer or officers, and within such local limits, as the Government appoints in this behalf.
 
 
(2) Any Inspector-General may hold simultaneously any other office in the service of the Republic.

question: Can the Inspector-General of Registration also hold another job in the government?
answer: Yes, according to Section 3(2), the Inspector-General of Registration can hold another position within the government's service simultaneously. This means one person can fulfill both roles.
law_reference: The Registration Act, 1908, Part II, Section 3

question: রেজিস্ট্রার জেনারেল নিয়োগ কিভাবে করা হয় এবং সরকারের ক্ষমতা কী?
answer: বাংলাদেশের জন্য রেজিস্টার জেনারেল নিয়োগ করার দায়িত্ব সরকারের (Section 3)। তবে, সরকার এই দায়িত্ব অন্য সরকারি কর্মকর্তাদের মধ্যে বিতরণ করতে পারে, সরাসরি কাউকে রেজিস্টার জেনারেল হিসেবে নিয়োগ না করে। যদি সরকার এ ব্যাপারে নির্দেশ দেয়, তাহলে অন্য কর্মকর্তারা নির্দিষ্ট এলাকায় রেজিস্টার জেনারেলের কাজ করতে পারেন।

question: How does the government decide which areas will be considered districts and sub-districts for registration purposes?
answer: Section 5(1) of The Registration Act, 1908 states that the government has the authority to form districts and sub-districts for the purposes of this Act. They can also change the boundaries of these districts and sub-districts as needed. It doesn't specify a particular process, simply that the government has this power.
law_reference: The Registration Act, 1908, Part II, Section 5
input_context:
5. (1) For the purposes of this Act, the Government shall form districts and sub-districts, and shall prescribe, and may alter, the limits of such districts and sub-districts.
 
 
(2) The districts and sub-districts formed under this section, together with the limits thereof, and every alteration of such limits shall be notified in the official Gazette.
 
 
(3) Every such alteration shall take effect on such day after the date of the notification as is therein mentioned.

question: If the government changes the boundaries of a district, how will I know about it?
answer: Section 5(2) explains that any changes made to the districts and sub-districts, including their boundaries, will be officially announced in the Government Gazette. This is the official publication where important legal notices are published, so you should check it to stay informed.

question: আমি জানতে চাই, সরকার যদি কোনো এলাকার সীমানা পরিবর্তন করে, তাহলে সেটি কবে থেকে কার্যকর হবে?
answer: ধারা ৫(৩) অনুযায়ী, সরকার কোনো এলাকার সীমানা পরিবর্তন করলে, সেটি গেজেটে বিজ্ঞপ্তির তারিখ থেকে কত দিনের পর কার্যকর হবে, সেটি বিজ্ঞপ্তিতে উল্লেখ করা থাকবে। অর্থাৎ, বিজ্ঞপ্তিতে যে তারিখ দেওয়া হবে, সেই তারিখ থেকে পরিবর্তিত সীমানা কার্যকর হবে।
law_reference: The Registration Act, 1908, Part II, Section 5

question: Who is allowed to be a Registrar or Sub-Registrar in Bangladesh, according to the law?
answer: According to Section 6 of The Registration Act, 1908, the government can appoint anyone they deem suitable, whether they are government employees (public officers) or not, to be a Registrar for a district or a Sub-Registrar for a sub-district. It’s the government’s discretion in choosing who fills these roles.

question: Where are the offices of the Registrar and Sub-Registrar located?
answer: Section 7(1) of The Registration Act, 1908 states that the government is required to establish an office called the 'office of the Registrar' in every district. Additionally, offices known as the 'office of the Sub-Registrar' or 'offices of the Joint Sub-Registrars' are to be established in every sub-district.
law_reference: The Registration Act, 1908, Part II, Section 7
input_context:
7.(1) Government shall establish in every district an office to be styled the office of the Registrar and in every sub-district an office or offices to be styled the office of the Sub-Registrar or the offices of the Joint Sub-Registrars.
 
 
(2) The Government may amalgamate with any office of a Registrar any office of a Sub-Registrar subordinate to such Registrar, and may authorize any Sub-Registrar whose office has been so amalgamated to exercise and perform, in addition to his own powers and duties, all or any of the powers and duties of the Registrar to whom he is subordinate:
 
 
Provided that no such authorization shall enable a Sub-Registrar to hear an appeal against an order passed by himself under this Act.

question: Can a Sub-Registrar ever perform the duties of a Registrar?
answer: Yes, according to Section 7(2), the government can authorize a Sub-Registrar to perform some or all of the duties of the Registrar to whom they are subordinate. However, this authorization does *not* allow the Sub-Registrar to hear appeals against decisions they themselves have made.

question: Who can be appointed as an Inspector of Registration-offices and what exactly do they do?
answer: According to Section 8(1) of The Registration Act, 1908, the Government has the power to appoint officers who will be known as Inspectors of Registration-offices. The Act doesn't detail specific duties, but it allows the government to define what those inspectors will be responsible for. Essentially, they are government officials overseeing registration offices.

question: What happens if the Registrar's office is empty, either because the Registrar is away or has left their position?
answer: Section 10 of the Registration Act, 1908 explains that if the Registrar is absent or their position is vacant, the Inspector-General of Registrations can appoint someone to temporarily fill the role. If the Inspector-General doesn't make an appointment, then the Judge of the District Court in the area where the Registrar's office is located will act as the Registrar until the government permanently fills the vacancy.
law_reference: The Registration Act, 1908, Part II, Section 10
input_context: 10. (1) When any Registrar, is absent otherwise than on duty in his district, or when his office is temporarily vacant, any person whom the Inspector-General appoints in this behalf, or, in default of such appointment, the Judge of the District Court within the local limits of whose jurisdiction the Registrar's office is situate, shall be the Registrar during such absence or until the Government fills up the vacancy.

question: If the Inspector-General doesn't appoint someone to act as Registrar while the official Registrar is away, who steps in?
answer: According to Section 10 of the Registration Act, 1908, if the Inspector-General fails to appoint a temporary Registrar, the Judge of the District Court responsible for the area where the Registrar's office is located will automatically take on the responsibilities of the Registrar until a permanent replacement is found by the government.

question: সরকার এই আইন অনুযায়ী রেজিস্ট্রি অফিস স্থাপন করতে পারবে কিনা? (Shorkar ei ain onujayi registri office sthapon korte parbe kina?)

question: Who is responsible for providing the books needed for registration officers to do their jobs?

question: I signed a contract to buy land a while ago, but it wasn't registered. Section 17A was recently introduced. What do I need to do now?
answer: According to Section 17B(1) of The Registration Act, 1908, you and the seller of the land need to present the sale agreement (instrument) or the contract itself to the registrar for registration within six months from the date Section 17A came into effect. Failing to do so within that timeframe could mean the contract becomes invalid.
law_reference: The Registration Act, 1908, Part III, Section 17B
input_context:
17B. (1) Where a contract for sale of immovable property is executed but not registered prior to coming into force of section 17A-
 
 
(a) the parties to the contract shall, within six months from the date of coming into force of that section,-
 
 
(i) present the instrument of sale of immovable property under the contract for registration, or
 
 
(ii) present the contract for sale itself for registration; or,
 
 
(b) either of the parties, if aggrieved for non compliance with any of the provisions mentioned in clause (a), shall, notwithstanding anything contained to the contrary in any law for the time being in force as to the law of Limitation, institute a suit for specific performance or recession of the contract within six months next after the expiry of the period mentioned in clause (a),
 
 
failing which the contract shall stand void.
 
 
(2) The provision of sub-section (1) shall not apply to any contract for sale of immovable property on the basis of which a suit has been instituted in a civil court before coming into force of section 17A.

question: What happens if one party doesn't comply with the registration requirements outlined in Section 17B, and the other party feels they've been wronged?
answer: Section 17B(1)(b) states that if one party is unhappy because the other party didn't follow the registration requirements, they can file a lawsuit for either specific performance (forcing the contract to be carried out) or to have the contract cancelled (recession) within six months after the initial six-month registration period has expired.  If they don't take this legal action within that timeframe, the contract becomes void.

question: I've made a gift of my land to my son. Does this document need to be registered?

law_reference: The Registration Act, 1908, Part III, Section 17
input_context:
17. (1) The following documents shall be registered, if the property to which they relate is situate in a district in which, and if they have been executed on or after the date on which, this Act came or comes into force, namely:-

(aa) declaration of heba under the Muslim Personal Law (Shariat);

(cc) instrument of mortgage referred to in section 59 of the Transfer of Property Act, 1882;
 
 
(d) leases of immoveable property from year to year, or for any term exceeding one year, or reserving a yearly rent;

question: I'm selling my land. Do I need to have a written agreement with the buyer, and is this agreement legally binding?
answer: Yes, according to Section 17A of The Registration Act, 1908, any contract for the sale of land (immovable property) must be in writing and signed by both you (the seller) and the buyer. This written agreement needs to be registered to be legally binding.  Without a written and registered agreement, the sale may not be enforceable in a court of law.

question: I have a property transfer document written in Arabic. Can I register it, or will the registration officer refuse because they don't understand Arabic?
answer: According to Section 19 of The Registration Act, 1908, if the document is in a language the registering officer doesn't understand (like Arabic, which may not be commonly used in the district), they *can* refuse to register it. However, you can still register the document if you provide a true translation of it into a language commonly used in the district and a true copy of the original document.  So, getting a qualified translator and providing a copy is essential.

question: I made a property sale agreement, but I had to cross something out and write a correction. Will the registration officer accept it?
answer: According to Section 20 of The Registration Act, 1908, the registering officer *may* refuse to register your document if it contains corrections like cross-outs or alterations. However, they aren’t automatically rejected. To ensure the document is accepted, both you and the other party who signed it must add your signature or initials next to the correction you made. This acknowledges that you both agree with the change.

answer: Section 20(2) of The Registration Act, 1908 states that if the registering officer decides to register a document containing alterations or corrections, they *must* record a note about those changes in the registration register. 21. (1) No non-testamentary document relating to immoveable property shall be accepted for registration unless it contains a description of such property sufficient to identify the same.
 
 
(2) Houses in towns shall be described as situate on the north or other side of the street or road (which should be specified) to which they front, and by their existing and former occupancies, and by their numbers if the houses in such street or road are numbered.
 
 
(3) Other houses and lands shall be described by their name, if any, and as being in the territorial division in which they are situate, and by their superficial contents, the roads and other properties on which they abut, and their existing occupancies, and also, whenever it is practicable, by reference to a Government map or survey.
 
 
(4) No non-testamentary document containing a map or plan of any property comprised therein shall be accepted for registration unless it is accompanied by a true copy of the map or plan, or, in case such property is situate in several districts, by such number of true copies of the map or plan as are equal to the number of such districts.

question: If my land borders multiple districts, how many copies of the map do I need to submit for registration?
answer: Section 21(4) of The Registration Act, 1908 states that if the property in your document is located in multiple districts, you must submit as many true copies of the map as there are districts. This ensures that the relevant authorities in each district have a record of the property’s boundaries.

question: বিক্রয়ের দলিল করার সময় জমির বর্ণনা কিভাবে দিতে হবে?
answer: জমির বিক্রয়ের দলিল করার সময়, জমিটি সঠিকভাবে চিহ্নিত করার জন্য পর্যাপ্ত বর্ণনা দিতে হবে।  রেজিস্ট্রেশন আইন, ১৯০৮ এর ধারা ২১ অনুযায়ী, আপনাকে জমির নাম (যদি থাকে), এটি কোন এলাকার মধ্যে অবস্থিত, এর আয়তন, এটি কোন রাস্তা বা অন্য সম্পত্তির সাথে borders, এবং আগের occupant-দের তথ্য উল্লেখ করতে হবে। সম্ভব হলে, সরকারি মানচিত্রের সাথে সংযোগ করে বর্ণনা দেওয়া ভালো। শহরের বাড়ির ক্ষেত্রে রাস্তার উত্তর বা অন্য কোন পাশে বাড়িটি অবস্থিত, পূর্বে কাদের দখলে ছিল, বাড়ির নম্বর ইত্যাদি তথ্য দিতে হবে।

question: I own a rural house. Does the government have the power to force me to describe my property using government maps when registering a document related to it?
answer: Yes, potentially. Section 22(1) of The Registration Act, 1908 allows the Government to create rules that require rural houses and lands to be described using government maps or surveys when registering documents related to them. question: What information needs to be included in a document when I'm transferring property, like selling my land, according to the law?
answer: According to Section 22A of The Registration Act, 1908, the document you use to transfer property must clearly state your intention to transfer, provide a complete description of the property being transferred, and describe the type of transaction taking place (like a sale or gift).
law_reference: The Registration Act, 1908, Part III, Section 22A
input_context:
22A. (1) Every instrument of transfer required to be compulsorily registered under this Act shall contain the particulars necessary to convey the intention of the parties, complete description of the properties to be transferred and nature of the transaction.
 
 
(2) Photographs of both the executant and the recipient shall be pasted on every instrument and the parties shall sign and put their left thumb impressions across their photographs in the instrument:
 
Provided that if any party is incapable of signing, he shall not be required to sign.
 
 
 
(3) The government shall, within three months of coming into force of the Registration (Amendment) Act, 2004 by notification in the official Gazette, prescribe a format for the purposes of this section.

question: I just signed a land sale agreement. How long do I have to register it with the authorities?
answer: According to Section 23 of The Registration Act, 1908, you generally have three months from the date you signed the agreement to present it for registration. If you miss this three-month window, the document likely won't be accepted for registration unless you have a valid reason and the proper officer allows it.

question: What happens if I have a court order (decree) that I need to register? Is the timeframe different?
answer: Section 23 of The Registration Act, 1908 allows for a copy of a court decree or order to be presented for registration within three months from the date it was made. However, if the decree or order is appealable, you have three months from the date it becomes final (meaning the appeal process is complete) to register it.

question: আমি একটি চুক্তি করেছি, সেটা রেজিস্ট্রি করার জন্য আমার কাছে কত সময় আছে? (Ami ekati chukti korechi, setta registry korar jonno amar aasche koto somoy ache?)

question: My property deed was registered by someone who wasn't authorized to do so. What can I do to make sure the registration is valid?
answer: Section 23A of The Registration Act, 1908 allows you to apply for re-registration of the document.  If a document requiring registration was registered by someone not authorized to present it, you have four months from when you realize the registration is invalid to submit the document for re-registration at the Registrar's office in the district where it was originally registered. The Registrar will then re-register the document as if it had been properly registered initially, and it will be considered valid from the date of the original registration.
law_reference: The Registration Act, 1908, Part IV, Section 23A
input_context:
23A. Notwithstanding anything to the contrary contained in this Act, if in any case a document requiring registration has been accepted for registration by a Registrar or Sub-Registrar from a person not duly empowered to present the same, and has been registered, any person claiming under such document may, within four months from this first becoming aware that the registration of such document is invalid, present such document or cause the same to be presented, in accordance with the provisions of Part VI for re-registration in the office of the Registrar of the district in which the document was originally registered; and upon the Registrar being satisfied that the document was so accepted for registration from a person not duly empowered to present the same, he shall proceed to the re-registration of the document as if it had not been previously registered, and as if such presentation for re-registration was a presentation for registration made within the time allowed therefor under Part IV, and all the provisions of this Act, as to registration of documents, shall apply to such re-registration; and such document, if duly re-registered in accordance with the provisions of this section, shall be deemed to have been duly registered for all purposes from the date of its original registration:
 
 
Provided that, within three months from the twelfth day of September, 1917, any person claiming under a document to which this section applies may present the same or cause the same to be presented for re-registration in accordance with this section, whatever may have been the time when he first became aware that the registration of the document was invalid.

question: Is there a deadline to apply for the re-registration under section 23A?
answer: Yes, there are deadlines. Generally, you have four months from the date you discover that the initial registration was invalid. However, there's a special provision: if your document falls under this section, you can apply for re-registration within three months from September 12, 1917, regardless of when you became aware of the registration issue. This latter deadline has passed.

question: If three people sign a deed, but they sign it on different days, how long do I have to get it registered?
answer: According to Section 24 of The Registration Act, 1908, you have four months from the date of *each* person's signature. This means the clock starts ticking for each individual signing the document, and you need to register the document within those four-month periods.

question: My friend and I signed a joint property agreement on separate days.  Can we register it later than four months after *my* signing date?
answer: No, Section 24 of The Registration Act states that the four-month window applies to *each* execution. You can't delay registration just because you signed later.  You must ensure registration happens within four months of *each* person's signing date.

question: I missed the deadline to register a document, but it was due to a sudden family emergency. Can I still register it?
answer: Yes, you might be able to. Section 25 of The Registration Act, 1908 allows the Registrar to accept a document for registration even if it's presented late, if the delay was due to urgent necessity or an unavoidable accident. However, the delay cannot exceed four months. You’ll likely have to pay a fine, which could be up to ten times the regular registration fee. You’ll need to apply for the Registrar’s direction.
law_reference: The Registration Act, 1908, Part IV, Section 25

(1) If, owing to urgent necessity or unavoidable accident, any document executed, or copy of a decree or order made, in Bangladesh is not presented for registration till after the expiration of the time hereinbefore prescribed in that behalf, the Registrar, in cases where the delay in presentation does not exceed four months, may direct that, on payment of a fine not exceeding ten times the amount of the proper registration-fee, such document shall be accepted for registration.
 
 
(2) Any application for such direction may be lodged with a Sub-Registrar, who shall forthwith forward it to the Registrar to whom he is subordinate.

question: I want to register a property sale deed. Where do I need to go? Is it based on where the whole property is located?
answer: According to Section 28 of The Registration Act, 1908, you need to present the document at the office of a Sub-Registrar.  The location of this office should be within the sub-district where the major portion of the property is situated.  However, if the property's major portion isn't in one sub-district, you can register it in a Sub-Registrar's office within any sub-district where a portion of the property exists.
law_reference: The Registration Act, 1908, Part V, Section 28

You can choose any office where all parties involved want the document to be registered.

answer: হ্যাঁ, আছে। রেজিস্ট্রেশন আইন, ১৯০৮ এর ধারা ৩১ অনুযায়ী, সাধারণত দলিল রেজিস্ট্রি করার জন্য অফিসে যেতে হয়। তবে, বিশেষ কারণ দর্শানো গেলে, রেজিস্ট্রি অফিসার আপনার বাড়িতে এসে দলিলটি রেজিস্ট্রি করতে পারেন। আপনার বিশেষ কারণটি সন্তোষজনক হলে, অফিসার আপনার বাড়ির адресуতে আসতে রাজি হতে পারেন।

question: My family member lives abroad. What official needs to authenticate a power of attorney document so I can register it in Bangladesh?
answer: According to Section 33 of The Registration Act, 1908, if the principal (the person granting power) resides outside of Bangladesh, the power of attorney needs to be executed before and authenticated by a Notary Public, any Court, Judge, Magistrate, Bangladesh Consul or Vice-Consul, or a representative of the Government.  This ensures that the document is legally recognized for registration purposes in Bangladesh.

input_context:
33. (1) For the purposes of section 32, the following powers-of-attorney shall alone be recognized, namely:-
 
 
(a) if the principal at the time of executing the power-of-attorney resides in any part of Bangladesh in which this Act is for the time being in force, a power-of-attorney executed before and authenticated by the Registrar or Sub-Registrar within whose district or sub-district the principal resides;
 
 
(b) if the principal at the time aforesaid resides in any other part of Bangladesh, a power-of-attorney executed before and authenticated by any Magistrate;
 
 
(c) if the principal at the time aforesaid does not reside in Bangladesh a power-of-attorney executed before and authenticated by a Notary Public, or any Court, Judge, Magistrate, Bangladesh Consul or Vice-Consul or representative of the Government:
 
 
Provided that the following persons shall not be required to attend at any registration-office or Court for the purpose executing any such power-of-attorney as is mentioned in clauses (a) and (b) of this section, namely:-

(ii) persons who are in jail under civil or criminal process; and
 
 
(iii) persons exempt by law from personal appearance in Court.
 
 
(2) In the case of every such person the Registrar or Sub-Registrar or Magistrate, as the case may be, if satisfied that the power-of-attorney has been voluntarily executed by the person purporting to be the principal, may attest the same without requiring his personal attendance at the office or Court aforesaid.
 
 
(3) To obtain evidence as to the voluntary nature of the execution, the Registrar or Sub-Registrar or Magistrate may either himself go to the house of the person purporting to be the principal, or to the jail in which he is confined, and examine him, or issue a commission for his examination.
 
 
(4) Any power-of-attorney mentioned in this section may be proved by the production of it without further proof when it purports on the face of it to have been executed before and authenticated by the person or Court hereinbefore mentioned in that behalf.

question: I need to register a property document. Does everyone who signed the document *have* to be present when I submit it for registration?
answer: Section 34(1) of The Registration Act, 1908 states that generally, yes, all the people who signed the document, or their authorized representatives (like power of attorney holders) must appear before the registering officer to have it registered. However, there's an exception: If it's an urgent situation or an unavoidable accident prevents everyone from appearing, the Registrar *might* allow registration after you pay a fine (up to ten times the registration fee) – but this is at the Registrar’s discretion. You'll need to apply to the Registrar for permission in such cases.
law_reference: The Registration Act, 1908, Part VI, Section 34
input_context:
34. (1) Subject to the provisions contained in this Part and in sections 41, 43, 45, 69, 75, 77, 88 and 89, no document shall be registered under this Act, unless the persons executing such document, or their representatives, assigns or agents authorized as aforesaid, appear before the registering officer within the time allowed for presentation under sections 23, 24, 25 and 26:
 
 
Provided that, if owing to urgent necessity or unavoidable accident all such persons do not so appear, the Registrar, in cases where the delay in appearing does not exceed four months, may direct that on payment of a fine not exceeding ten times the amount of the proper registration fee, in addition to the fine, if any, payable under section 25, the document may be registered.
 
 
(2) Appearances under sub-section (1) may be simultaneous or at different times.
 
 
(3) The registering officer shall thereupon-
 
 
(a) enquire whether or not such document was executed by the persons by whom it purports to have been executed;
 
 
(b) satisfy himself as to the identity of the persons appearing before him and alleging that they have executed the document; and
 
 
(c) in the case of any person appearing as a representative, assign or agent, satisfy himself of the right of such persons so to appear.
 
 
(4) Any application for a direction under the proviso to sub-section (1) may be lodged with a Sub-Registrar, who shall forthwith forward it to the Registrar to whom he is sub-ordinate.
 
 
(5) Nothing in this section applies to copies of decrees or orders.

answer: Section 34(3)(c) allows a representative, assignee, or agent to appear on behalf of the person who signed the document. This means you will need to provide legal documentation proving your authority, such as a power of attorney or a duly authorized agency agreement. The registering officer needs to verify that your right to act as their representative is legitimate.

question: What needs to happen for a document to be registered if everyone who signed it is present and the registration officer knows who they are?
answer: According to Section 35 of The Registration Act, 1908, Part VI, if all the people who signed the document appear in person, and the registering officer is satisfied they are who they claim to be, and they all admit to signing the document, then the registering officer *shall* register the document following the procedures outlined in sections 58 to 61. This means the registration will proceed as normal.

question: আমার দেখা একটি রেজিস্ট্রেশন অফিসার যদি বলেন যে একজন স্বাক্ষরকারী দলিলটিতে স্বাক্ষর করেননি, তাহলে কি হবে? (What happens if a registration officer says someone who supposedly signed a document didn't sign it?)
answer: যদি কোনো ব্যক্তি যিনি কাগজে স্বাক্ষর করার কথা, তিনি স্বাক্ষর করার কথা অস্বীকার করেন, তাহলে Section 35(3) অনুযায়ী, রেজিস্ট্রেশন অফিসার সেই ব্যক্তির ক্ষেত্রে দলিলটি নথিভুক্ত করতে পারবেন না। যদি অফিসার কোনো তালিকাভুক্তার (Registrar) হন, তবে তাকে Part XII-এর নিয়ম অনুসরণ করতে হবে। সরকার সরকারি গেজেটে বিজ্ঞপ্তি দিয়ে কিছু সাব-রেজিস্ট্রারকে বিশেষ পরিস্থিতিতে রেজিস্ট্রারের মতো ক্ষমতা দিতে পারে। (According to Section 35(3), if a person who supposedly signed a document denies signing it, the registration officer will not be able to register the document concerning that person. If the officer is a Registrar, they must follow the procedure prescribed in Part XII. The government can designate certain Sub-Registrars to act as Registrars in specific circumstances through a notification in the official Gazette.)
law_reference: The Registration Act, 1908, Part VI, Section 35
input_context:
35. (1) (a) If all the persons executing the document appear personally before the registering officer and are personally known to him, or if he be otherwise satisfied that they are the persons they represent themselves to be, and if they all admit the execution of the document, or
 
 
(b) if in the case of any person appearing by a representative, assign or agent, such representative, assign or agent admits the execution, or
 
 
(c) if the person executing the document is dead, and his representative or assign appears before the registering officer and admits the execution,
 
 
the registering officer shall register the document as directed in sections 58 to 61, inclusive.
 
 
(2) the registering officer may, in order to satisfy himself that the persons appearing before him are the persons they represent themselves to be, or for any other purpose contemplated by this Act, examine any one present in his office.
 
 
(3) (a) If any person by whom the document purports to be executed denies its execution, or
 
 
(b) if any such person appears to the registering officer to be a minor, an idiot or a lunatic, or
 
 
(c) if any person by whom the document purports to be executed is dead, and his representative or assign denies its execution, the registering officer shall refuse to register the document as to the person so denying, appearing or dead:
 
 
Provided that, where such officer is a Registrar, he shall follow the procedure prescribed in Part XII:
 
 
Provided further that the Government may, by notification in the official Gazette, declare that any Sub-Registrar named in the notification shall, in respect of documents the execution of which is denied, by deemed to be a Registrar for the purposes of this sub-section and of Part XII.

question: I want to register a property deed, but the seller is refusing to come to the registration office. Can the registration officer force them to appear?
answer: Yes, under Section 36 of The Registration Act, 1908, Part VII, if you, as the person presenting the document for registration, request it, the registering officer can order a summons to be issued. This summons, delivered by an officer or court directed by the government, will require the person whose presence is necessary to appear at the registration office, either in person or through an authorized representative, at a specified time. This helps ensure the registration process can proceed if a party is hesitant or unable to attend willingly.
law_reference: The Registration Act, 1908, Part VII, Section 36

If any person presenting any document for registration or claiming under any document, which is capable of being so presented, desires the appearance of any person whose presence or testimony is necessary for the registration of such document, the registering officer may, in his discretion call upon such officer or Court as the Government directs in this behalf to issue a summons requiring him to appear at the registration-office, either in person or by duly authorized agent, as in the summons may be mentioned, and at a time named therein.

question: My signature on a document is being questioned. Can I request someone who witnessed my signature to appear during registration to verify it?
answer: Absolutely. Section 36 of The Registration Act, 1908 allows you to do just that. If a witness's testimony is needed for the registration of a document, and you want them to be present, the registering officer has the power to order a summons requiring their appearance. This allows the officer to clarify any questions about the witness’s testimony directly, contributing to a smoother and more secure registration process.

question: আমি একটি দলিল (deed) দাখিল করতে চাই, কিন্তু অন্য পক্ষ (other party) উপস্থিত থাকতে রাজি হচ্ছে না। তাহলে কি নিবন্ধন কর্মকর্তা (registration officer) তাদের উপস্থিতির জন্য বাধ্য করতে পারবেন?
answer: হ্যাঁ, নিবন্ধন আইন, ১৯০৮ এর ধারা ৩৬ অনুযায়ী, আপনি যদি দলিল দাখিলের জন্য সংশ্লিষ্ট ব্যক্তিকে উপস্থিত করতে চান এবং তিনি রাজি না হন, তাহলে নিবন্ধন কর্মকর্তা একটি সমন জারির নির্দেশ দিতে পারেন। এই সমন সরকারের নির্দেশিত কোনো সরকারি কর্মকর্তা বা আদালতের মাধ্যমে জারি করা হবে এবং যার উপস্থিতি প্রয়োজন, তাকে নির্দিষ্ট সময়ে নিবন্ধন অফিসে উপস্থিত থাকতে বলা হবে। এটি নিশ্চিত করে যে, যে কোনো পক্ষের অনিচ্ছা সত্ত্বেও নিবন্ধন প্রক্রিয়াটি সম্পন্ন করা যেতে পারে।

question: I need to get someone to appear in court regarding a land registration issue. How do I ensure they receive a formal notice to appear?
answer: According to Section 37 of The Registration Act, 1908, Part VII, to ensure someone receives a formal notice (a summons), you need to pay the required peon’s fee to the officer or court. They will then issue the summons and arrange for it to be delivered to the person whose appearance is being requested. This ensures legal compliance in compelling their attendance.
law_reference: The Registration Act, 1908, Part VII, Section 37

question: What happens if I don't pay the peon's fee to get a summons issued according to this law?
answer: Section 37 of The Registration Act, 1908, Part VII states that the officer or court *will not* issue the summons unless the required peon’s fee is paid. Without payment, the process of formally notifying someone to appear legally cannot proceed. You must pay the fee before a summons can be issued and served.

question: আমি কিভাবে নিশ্চিত করব যে একজন ব্যক্তি জমি সংক্রান্ত একটি মামলার জন্য আদালতে উপস্থিত হওয়ার জন্য একটি আনুষ্ঠানিক নোটিশ পেয়েছে?
answer: রেজিস্ট্রেশন আইন, ১৯০৮ এর ধারা ৩৭ অনুযায়ী, কোনো ব্যক্তিকে জমি সংক্রান্ত মামলার জন্য আদালতে উপস্থিত হওয়ার জন্য একটি আনুষ্ঠানিক নোটিশ (summons) পেতে হলে, আপনাকে প্রথমে সংশ্লিষ্ট কর্মকর্তা বা আদালতের কাছে নির্ধারিত পেয়নিকের ফি জমা দিতে হবে। এরপর তারা summons ইস্যু করবে এবং সেটি ব্যক্তির কাছে পৌঁছে দেবে।
law_reference: The Registration Act, 1908, Part VII, Section 37
input_context: 37. The officer or Court, upon receipt of the peon's fee payable in such cases, shall issue the summons accordingly, and cause it to be served upon the person whose appearance is so required.

question: I'm very sick and it's difficult for me to travel. Do I have to go to the registration office in person to register a document?
answer: According to Section 38 of The Registration Act, 1908, Part VII, if you are physically unable to attend the registration office without risking or causing yourself serious inconvenience due to bodily infirmity, you are exempt from being required to appear in person. The registering officer can then either visit you at your home or issue a commission to examine you.
law_reference: The Registration Act, 1908, Part VII, Section 38
input_context:
38. (1) (a) A person who by reason of bodily infirmity is unable without risk or serious inconvenience to appear at the registration-office, or
 
 
(b) a person in jail under civil or criminal process, or
 
 
(c) persons exempt by law from personal appearance in Court, and who would but for the provision next hereinafter contained be required to appear in person at the registration-office,
 
 
shall not be required so to appear.
 
 
(2) In the case of every such person the registering officer shall either himself go to the house of such person, or to the jail in which he is confined, and examine him or issue a commission for his examination.

question: I'm currently in jail. Do I still have to appear at the registration office to register a document?
answer: Section 38 of The Registration Act, 1908, Part VII, states that if you are in jail under civil or criminal process, you are exempt from being required to appear in person at the registration office. The registering officer can visit you in jail or issue a commission to examine you.

question: আমার শারীরিক অসুস্থতার কারণে রেজিস্ট্রেশন অফিসে যাওয়া আমার জন্য কঠিন। সেক্ষেত্রে আমার কি করতে হবে?

question: I need to bring someone to court to testify about a document I’m registering. How does the law handle ensuring they appear?
answer: Section 39 of the Registration Act, 1908 essentially says that the same rules used to get witnesses to appear in regular civil court cases apply when you need someone to come to court related to a registration matter. This means the court can issue summons and commissions to compel their attendance and also handle payment for their time and travel.
law_reference: The Registration Act, 1908, Part VII, Section 39

question: If a witness refuses to come to court regarding a registered document, what can the court do?
answer: Section 39 of the Registration Act, 1908 states that the court has the power to issue a summons or a commission. These are legal orders that compel a person to appear in court.  If someone ignores a summons, the court can issue a commission, which is a formal request to another court or authority to enforce the summons.  The rules for civil court cases apply here.

question: আমার রেজিস্ট্রেশন সংক্রান্ত একটি মামলার জন্য একজন সাক্ষীকে আদালতে আনা দরকার। এই ক্ষেত্রে সাক্ষীর উপস্থিতি নিশ্চিত করার জন্য আইন কিভাবে কাজ করে?

question: I'm the person who wrote my will. Can I register it myself?
answer: Yes, absolutely! According to Section 40 of The Registration Act, 1908, Part VIII, you, as the person who created the will (the testator), are entitled to present it to a Registrar or Sub-Registrar for registration.
law_reference: The Registration Act, 1908, Part VIII, Section 40
input_context:
40. (1) The testator, or after his death any person claiming as executor or otherwise under a will, may present it to any Registrar or Sub-Registrar for registration.
 
 
(2) The donor, or after his death the donee, of any authority to adopt, or the adoptive son, may present it to any registrar or Sub-Registrar for registration.

question: My father recently passed away and he left a will. Who can take his will to be registered now?
answer: Section 40, Part VIII of The Registration Act, 1908 states that after the testator (the person who wrote the will) passes away, any person claiming to be an executor or otherwise under the will can present it to a Registrar or Sub-Registrar for registration. This means someone who is named in the will to handle its execution can do so.

question: আমার দাদী একটি দত্তক নেওয়ার অনুমতিপত্র তৈরি করেছিলেন। তিনি মারা যাওয়ার পরে, কে এটি রেজিস্ট্রি করতে পারবে?
answer: দত্তক নেওয়ার অনুমতিপত্রটি রেজিস্ট্রি করার জন্য, আপনার দাদী যিনি অনুমতিপত্রটি তৈরি করেছিলেন, তার মৃত্যুর পরে, আপনি (donee) অথবা দত্তক নেওয়া সন্তান এটি রেজিস্ট্রি করতে পারবেন। Registration Act, 1908 এর Part VIII এর Section 40 অনুযায়ী, এটি করার অধিকার রয়েছে।

question: My father passed away. I have his will, but I wasn't present when he signed it. Can I still get the will registered?
answer: Yes, you can. According to Section 41 of The Registration Act, 1908, Part VIII, even if you weren't present when your father signed the will, you can still register it. However, the registering officer needs to be satisfied that your father did indeed execute the will, that he is now deceased, and that you are legally entitled to present the will for registration under Section 40. You will likely need to provide supporting documents and potentially testify to prove these conditions.

(a) that the will or authority was executed by the testator or donor, as the case may be;
 
 
(b) that the testator or donor is dead; and
 
 
(c) that the person presenting the will or authority is, under section 40, entitled to present the same.

question: What does it mean by ‘entitled to present the same’ under Section 40 in relation to registering a will?
answer: Section 41 of The Registration Act, 1908 states that someone presenting a will for registration must be ‘entitled to present the same’ under Section 40. The registering officer will investigate to ensure that the person presenting the will has a legal right to do so.

question: আমার বাবা একটি উইল করেছেন, কিন্তু তিনি মারা গেছেন। আমি কিভাবে সেই উইলটি রেজিস্ট্রি করব?
answer: আপনার বাবার উইল রেজিস্ট্রি করার জন্য, আপনাকে Section 41, The Registration Act, 1908 অনুযায়ী প্রক্রিয়া অনুসরণ করতে হবে। যেহেতু আপনার বাবা মারা গেছেন, তাই আপনাকে প্রমাণ করতে হবে যে তিনি উইলটি করেছেন (অর্থাৎ, তিনি স্বাক্ষর করেছেন), তিনি এখন মৃত, এবং আপনি Section 40 অনুযায়ী উইলটি উপস্থাপন করার জন্য উপযুক্ত ব্যক্তি। রেজিস্ট্রিং অফিসার আপনার পরিচয় এবং আপনার অধিকার সম্পর্কিত কাগজপত্র দেখতে চাইতে পারেন।
law_reference: The Registration Act, 1908, Part VIII, Section 41
input_context:
41. (1) A will or an authority to adopt, presented for registration by the testator or donor, may be registered in the same manner as any other document.

question: I want to make sure my will is safe. Can I give it to the Registrar's office to keep, and is there anything I need to do when I do so?
answer: Yes, you can. Section 42 of The Registration Act, 1908 allows you to deposit your will with the Registrar. You, or someone you authorize (your agent), can take your will to the Registrar's office and keep it sealed in an envelope. The envelope needs to be clearly labeled with your name and the name of your agent (if you have one), and a brief description of what's inside.

question: My father left a sealed will for me to deposit. What exactly does the Registrar need to do when I hand it over?
answer: According to Section 43 of The Registration Act, 1908, when you, or your authorized agent, submit a sealed will, the Registrar will first record certain details in Register-book No. 5. This includes a copy of the inscription on the cover, the date and time of submission, and the names of any witnesses who can confirm your identity or the identity of your agent. They will also note any markings on the seal. Following this, the sealed will will be placed in a fire-proof box for safekeeping.

(2) The Registrar shall then place and retain the sealed cover in his fire-proof box.

question: আমার বাবা একটি সিল করা উইল রেজিস্ট্রি অফিসে জমা দিতে বলেছেন। সেখানে কী কী তথ্য রেজিস্টার নথিভুক্ত করবেন?
answer: রেজিস্ট্রেশন আইন, ১৯০৮ এর ধারা ৪৩ অনুযায়ী, যখন আপনি বা আপনার কর্তৃক নিযুক্ত প্রতিনিধি একটি সিল করা উইল রেজিস্ট্রি অফিসে জমা দেবেন, তখন রেজিস্টার রেজিস্টার-বুক নং ৫-এ কিছু বিবরণ লিপিবদ্ধ করবেন। এর মধ্যে কভারের উপরে লেখা, জমা দেওয়ার তারিখ ও সময় এবং আপনার পরিচয় বা আপনার প্রতিনিধির পরিচয় নিশ্চিত করতে পারে এমন কোনো ব্যক্তির নাম অন্তর্ভুক্ত থাকবে। রেজিস্টার সিলের উপরে কোনো চিহ্ন থাকলে তা-ও নোট করবেন। এরপর সিল করা উইল সুরক্ষার জন্য একটি অগ্নি-প্রতিরোধী বাক্সে রাখা হবে।

question: আমি আমার উইল রেজিস্টারের কাছে জমা দিয়েছি। এখন আমি যদি সেটি ফেরত পেতে চাই, তাহলে কিভাবে পাব?

question: My father deposited a will with a registrar before he passed away. How do I get a copy of the will and ensure it's executed?
answer: According to Section 45 of The Registration Act, 1908, Part IX, if you, as an applicant, apply to the registrar who holds your father's deposited will, and the registrar confirms he is deceased, the registrar will copy the contents of the sealed cover into his book No. 3 and then deliver the original will to you, as his nominee or representative. This happens at your expense for the copying.

question: I'm trying to contest a will. Does this law affect my ability to do so, especially considering the Succession Act of 1925?
answer: Section 46(1) of The Registration Act, 1908 specifically states that nothing in this Act affects the provisions of the Succession Act, 1925. This means your right to contest a will under the Succession Act remains unaffected by the rules about registering wills in this Act. The courts still have the power to order the production of the will for examination during the contestation process.

question: My uncle left a will with a registrar before 1962. Can they just get rid of it now?
answer: Section 46A of The Registration Act, 1908 allows for wills deposited with a registrar before the Registration (Amendment) Ordinance, 1962, to be destroyed if they haven’t been registered. The registrar follows a specific procedure, including sending notices to the depositor and their nominee, before doing so. It's important to note that this section allows destruction of those wills that haven’t been properly registered.
law_reference: The Registration Act, 1908, Part IX, Section 46A
input_context:
46A. (1) Any will in deposit with a Registrar at the commencement of the Registration (Amendment) Ordinance, 1962, and any will thereafter deposited may be destroyed after following the procedure hereinafter provided, if the will is not registered before such destruction.
 
 
(2) Every registering officer shall on the first day of July in the year next after the commencement of the Registration (Amendment) Ordinance, 1962, and on the first day of July in every succeeding third year, send by post a notice to every depositor and his nominee, inquiring about the depositor's present address and shall enter on the cover and in his registers any new address supplied in response to such notice.
 
 
(3) If, as a result of such notice or in any other manner, the Registrar is satisfied that the testator has died, the Registrar shall, after making an entry in his books as to the death of the testator and the nature of the information on which he has acted, open the cover in the presence of a judicial officer (not below the rank of Assistant Judge. He shall thereupon issue a notice to the executor, if any, and also to such other person or persons deriving any benefit under the will as the two officers may determine, informing them about the existence of the will and also that unless steps are taken within a period of six months therefrom for registration of the will the document shall be liable to be destroyed.
 
 
(4) Notwithstanding the expiry of the period specified in the notice, until the will is actually destroyed in accordance with the provision of the Destruction of Records Act, 1917, the registration of the same can be effected, at the request of the person entitled thereto, on payment of the proper charges.

They then send notices to the executor and anyone else benefiting from the will, informing them about the will’s existence and the risk of destruction if it's not registered within six months.

(4) Notwithstanding the expiry of the period specified in the notice, until the will is actually destroyed in accordance with the provision of the Destruction of Records Act, 1917, the registration of the same can be effected, at the request of the person entitled thereto, on payment of the proper charges.

question: আমার বাবা একটি উইল রেজিস্ট্রি অফিসে জমা রেখেছেন, কিন্তু সেটি এখনো রেজিস্ট্রি করা হয়নি। যদি রেজিস্ট্রি না করা হয়, তাহলে সেটি কি বাতিল হয়ে যাবে?
answer: রেজিস্ট্রেশন আইন, ১৯০৮ এর ধারা ৪৬এ অনুযায়ী, যদি কোনো উইল রেজিস্ট্রি অফিসে জমা রাখা হয় কিন্তু রেজিস্ট্রি করা না হয়, তাহলে সেটি বাতিল করা হতে পারে। রেজিস্ট্রি করার জন্য প্রথম সুযোগ পাওয়ার পরও যদি সেটি রেজিস্ট্রি না করা হয়, তাহলে আইন অনুযায়ী সেটি বাতিল করার প্রক্রিয়া শুরু হতে পারে। তবে, এটি করার আগে রেজিস্ট্রি অফিস প্রথমে উইল প্রদানকারীর বর্তমান ঠিকানা জানার জন্য নোটিশ পাঠাবে এবং অন্যান্য নিয়মকানুন অনুসরণ করবে।

question: I signed a sale agreement for my land last month, but we only registered it today. Does the agreement only become legally binding from today, the date of registration?
answer: No, according to Section 47 of The Registration Act, 1908, Part X, the registered document (your sale agreement) operates from the time it would have been legally binding if registration wasn't required.  So, it's binding from the date you signed it last month, not from the date of registration today. Registration just provides official record of that agreement.
law_reference: The Registration Act, 1908, Part X, Section 47
input_context: 47. A registered document shall operate from the time which it would have commenced to operate if no registration thereof had been required or made, and not from the time of its registration.

question: If a property was transferred informally a year ago, and we now decide to register the document, from when does the registration legally affect the transfer?
answer: Section 47 of The Registration Act, 1908, Part X, clarifies that the registration doesn't change when the transfer initially took effect. The registered document operates from the date the transfer was originally intended to be effective – that is, the time it would have commenced to operate if registration hadn’t been required. It doesn't 'restart' from the date of registration.

question: বিক্রয় দলিল (sale agreement) নিবন্ধিত করার পরে, এটি কবে থেকে আইনত কার্যকর হবে? নিবন্ধনের তারিখ থেকেই কি?
answer: ধারা ৪৭ অনুযায়ী, যখন কোনো দলিল নিবন্ধিত করা হয়, তখন সেটি কবে থেকে কার্যকর হবে, তা নির্ভর করে যদি নিবন্ধনের প্রয়োজন না হতো, তাহলে সেটি কবে থেকে কার্যকর হতো, তার ওপর। দলিলটি নিবন্ধনের তারিখ থেকে নয়, বরং সেই তারিখ থেকে কার্যকর হবে যখন এটি স্বাভাবিকভাবে কার্যকর হওয়ার কথা ছিল।

question: I have a registered sale deed for my land. My neighbor claims they had a verbal agreement with the previous owner about a boundary line before I got the deed. Does their verbal agreement matter?
answer: Section 48 of The Registration Act, 1908 states that your registered sale deed takes precedence over any prior oral agreement regarding the property.  Unless your neighbor delivered possession of the property and that delivery constitutes a valid transfer under the law, their verbal agreement with the previous owner is not enforceable against you.  The registered deed prevails.

Provided that a mortgage by deposit or title-deeds as defined in section 58 of the Transfer of Property Act, 1882, shall take effect against any mortgage-deed subsequently executed and registered which relate to the same property.

question: Someone gave me a 'power of attorney' for a property years ago and registered it. Later, another registered mortgage deed was created for the same property. Which document is valid against the later one?
answer: According to Section 48 of The Registration Act, 1908, if you have a registered power of attorney (considered a title deed under section 58 of the Transfer of Property Act, 1882) relating to a property, it takes effect against any subsequent mortgage deed registered later for the same property. answer: রেজিস্ট্রেশন আইন, ১৯০৮ এর ধারা ৪৮ অনুযায়ী, আপনার রেজিস্ট্রি করা দলিলের (sale deed)  আগে যদি কোনো মৌখিক চুক্তি (oral agreement) হয়ে থাকে, সেটি বাতিল বলে গণ্য হবে। ক্রেতা সম্পত্তিটি রেজিস্ট্রি করার সময় রেজিস্টার্ড দলিলের মাধ্যমেই স্বত্ব (ownership) লাভ করেছেন। যদি ক্রেতা আপনার কাছ থেকে দখল বুঝে না থাকেন এবং সেই দখল হস্তান্তর আইন অনুযায়ী বৈধ না হয়, তাহলে তার মৌখিক প্রতিশ্রুতি (oral promise) কার্যকর হবে না।

question: I sold my land and have a signed agreement, but didn't register it. Is the agreement legally binding?
answer: According to Section 49 of the Registration Act, 1908, Part X, the agreement you mentioned won't create, declare, assign, limit, or extinguish any right, title, or interest in the land unless it is registered. This means that without registration, the agreement, as it stands, is not legally effective in creating ownership or rights to the land. It essentially has no legal standing.
law_reference: The Registration Act, 1908, Part X, Section 49

49. No document required to be registered under this Act or under any earlier law providing for or relating to registration of documents shall-

(b) confer any power to adopt,
 
 
unless it has been registered.

question: My grandfather left me a will concerning property, but it wasn't registered. Does that will legally transfer ownership to me?
answer: Section 49 of The Registration Act, 1908, states that if a will, which is a document required for registration when dealing with immovable property, is not registered, it cannot operate to transfer ownership rights. Until the will is registered, you do not legally have ownership of the property, even though the will exists.

question: I have a sale deed that isn't registered. My neighbor has a later, registered document claiming ownership of the same land. Will their registered document automatically supersede mine?
answer: Not necessarily. Section 50 of The Registration Act, 1908 states that a properly registered document generally takes effect against an unregistered document affecting the same property. However, if you were already in possession of the land based on the unregistered document and meet the conditions of Section 53A of the Transfer of Property Act, 1882, you may still be entitled to certain rights. Additionally, you can potentially enforce a contract related to the unregistered document in a specific performance suit against someone claiming under a subsequent registered document, as per the provisions outlined in Section 50(2).

question: আমার একটি কেনাবেচার দলিল আছে যা নিবন্ধিত নয়। অন্যজনের একটি নিবন্ধিত দলিল আছে যেখানে একই জমির মালিকানা দাবি করা হয়েছে। সেক্ষেত্রে, নিবন্ধিত দলিলটি কি আমার দলিলে অগ্রাধিকার পাবে?

question: What kinds of records are registration offices required to keep, and what is each book used for?
answer: Section 51 of The Registration Act, 1908 outlines the books that registration offices and the offices of Registrars must maintain. Book 1 is for records related to immovable property (like land), Book 2 documents reasons for refusing registration, Book 3 is for wills and adoption authorities, and Book 4 is a general miscellaneous register. The Registrar's offices keep Book 5 for deposits of wills. These books ensure organized record-keeping for various legal transactions.
law_reference: The Registration Act, 1908, Part XI, Section 51
input_context:
51. (1) The following books shall be kept in the several offices hereinafter named, namely:-
 
 
A-In all registration offices-
 
 
Book 1, “Register of on-testamentary documents relating to immoveable property”;
 
 
Book 2, “Record of reasons for refusal to register”;
 
 
Book 3, “Register of wills and authorities to adopt”; and
 
 
Book 4, “Miscellaneous Register”;
 
 
B-In the offices of Registrars-
 
 
Book 5, Register of deposits of wills.”
 
 
(2) In Book 1 shall be entered or filed all documents or memoranda registered under sections 17, 18 and 89 which relate to immoveable property, and are not wills.
 
 
(3) In Book 4 shall be entered all documents registered under section 18 which do not relate to immoveable property.
 
 
(4) Nothing in this section shall be deemed to require more than one set of books where the office of the Registrar has been amalgamated with the office of a Sub-Registrar.
 
 
(5) If, in the opinion of the Registrar, any of the books mentioned in sub-section (1) is in danger of being destroyed or becoming illegible wholly partially, the Registrar may, by a written order, direct such book or portion thereof as he thinks fit, to be recopied and authenticated in such manner as may be prescribed by rules, and the copy prepared and authenticated under such direction shall, for all purposes of this Act and of the Evidence Act, 1872, be deemed to be the original book or portion and all references in this Act to the original book shall be deemed to be to the book or portion so recopied and authenticated.

answer: Section 51(4) clarifies that if a Registrar's office is merged with a Sub-Registrar's office, the law doesn't require maintaining multiple sets of these books. Essentially, they only need to keep one set, streamlining the record-keeping process for amalgamated offices.

(5) If, in the opinion of the Registrar, any of the books mentioned in sub-section (1) is in danger of being destroyed or becoming illegible wholly partially, the Registrar may, by a written order, direct such book or portion thereof as he thinks fit, to be recopied and authenticated in such manner as may be prescribed by rules, and the copy prepared and authenticated under such direction shall, for all purposes of this Act and of the Evidence Act, 1872, be deemed to be the original book or portion and all references in this Act to the original book shall be deemed to be to the book or portion so recopied and authenticated.

question: যদি কোনো রেজিস্ট্রি বই নষ্ট হয়ে যায় বা লেখা অস্পষ্ট হয়ে পড়ে, তাহলে কি করতে হবে?
answer: ধারা ৫1(৫) অনুযায়ী, যদি রেজিস্ট্রি অফিসের কোনো বই নষ্ট হয়ে যায় বা লেখার অক্ষরগুলো অস্পষ্ট হয়ে যায়, তাহলে রেজিস্ট্রি কর্মকর্তা লিখিত নির্দেশের মাধ্যমে সেই বইয়ের একটি নতুন কপি তৈরি করতে পারেন। এই নতুন কপিটিকে মূল বইয়ের মতোই গণ্য করা হবে এবং এটি আইন ও সাক্ষ্য আইনের অধীনে বৈধতা পাবে।

question: What happens when I submit a document for registration? Do I get any proof that I submitted it?
answer: Section 52(1)(b) of The Registration Act, 1908 states that when you present a document for registration, the registering officer *must* give you a receipt for that document. This receipt serves as proof that you submitted the document for registration.

question: আমার জমির দলিল রেজিস্ট্রি করার সময় রেজিস্ট্রি অফিসার কী করবেন? আমি কি কোনো রসিদ পাবো?
answer: রেজিস্ট্রি আইন, ১৯০৮ এর ধারা ৫২(১)(খ) অনুযায়ী, যখন আপনি আপনার জমির দলিল রেজিস্ট্রি করার জন্য জমা দেবেন, রেজিস্ট্রি অফিসার আপনাকে অবশ্যই একটি রসিদ দিতে হবে। এই রসিদটি প্রমাণ হিসেবে কাজ করবে যে আপনি দলিলটি রেজিস্ট্রি করার জন্য জমা দিয়েছেন।  রেজিস্ট্রি অফিসার দলিলের তারিখ, সময় ও স্থান এবং আপনার স্বাক্ষর দলিলের উপর লিখে রাখবেন।

question: I'm selling a piece of land I inherited. What documents does the Registering Officer need to see before registering the sale deed?
answer: According to Section 52A of The Registration Act, 1908, if you inherited the property, you need to provide the Registering Officer with the latest 'Khatian' (land record) prepared under the State Acquisition and Tenancy Act, 1950, in the name of either yourself (as the seller) or your predecessor (the person who passed it on to you).  Additionally, you'll need to include the nature of the property, its price, a map with boundaries, a 25-year ownership history, and an affidavit confirming you haven't transferred it before and have a legal right to sell it.
law_reference: The Registration Act, 1908, Part XI, Section 52A

question: I'm selling a property I bought directly from a developer. What information must I provide to the Registering Officer?
answer: Section 52A of The Registration Act, 1908 requires you to provide several details to the Registering Officer. This includes the latest 'Khatian' under the State Acquisition and Tenancy Act, 1950 (in your name, as you are the owner), a description of the property's nature, its price, a map with boundaries, a 25-year ownership history (this might be tricky for a recently purchased property, so be prepared to explain), and an affidavit confirming you haven't sold it before and have the legal right to sell it.
law_reference: The Registration Act, 1908, Part XI, Section 52A

question: আমি একটি জমি বিক্রি করতে চাই। রেজিস্ট্রি করার সময় আমাকে কী কী তথ্য সরবরাহ করতে হবে?
answer: রেজিস্ট্রি আইন, ১৯০৮ এর ধারা ৫২(এ) অনুসারে, জমি বিক্রির সময় আপনাকে রেজিস্ট্রি অফিসারকে বেশ কিছু তথ্য সরবরাহ করতে হবে। এর মধ্যে রয়েছে স্টেট অ্যাকুইজিশন অ্যান্ড টেনেন্সি আইন, ১৯৫০ এর অধীনে প্রস্তুত করা সর্বশেষ ‘খতিয়ান’ (আপনার নামে), সম্পত্তির ধরণ, দাম, সীমানা সহ একটি মানচিত্র, গত ২৫ বছরের মালিকানার ইতিহাস এবং একটি হলফনামা, যেখানে আপনি নিশ্চিত করবেন যে আপনি আগে এটি বিক্রি করেননি এবং আপনার আইনসম্মতভাবে বিক্রির অধিকার আছে।
law_reference: The Registration Act, 1908, Part XI, Section 52A

question: Why do the records in the registration books have numbers, and how often do these numbers reset?
answer: Section 53 of the Registration Act, 1908 states that all entries in the registration books must be numbered continuously. This numbering starts at the beginning of each year and ends at the year's end. So, you'll see a sequence of numbers for each year, and a new sequence begins at the start of the following year. This helps in keeping track of the order in which documents were registered.
law_reference: The Registration Act, 1908, Part XI, Section 53

question: If I'm looking for a document registered in 2022, how will the numbering system help me?
answer: Section 53 of the Registration Act, 1908 dictates that each year has its own numbered series of entries. Therefore, if you're looking for a document registered in 2022, you'll be looking for a number within the 2022 numbering sequence within the relevant registration book.  The numbering allows officials to quickly locate documents within a specific year’s records.

question: রেজিস্ট্রির বইগুলোতে কেন নম্বর দেওয়া হয়, এবং এই নম্বরগুলো কতদিন পর পর পরিবর্তন হয়?
answer: রেজিস্ট্রির বইগুলোতে প্রতিটি এন্ট্রিকে চিহ্নিত করার জন্য নম্বর দেওয়া হয়। রেজিস্ট্রেশন আইন, ১৯০৮ এর ৫৩ নম্বর ধারা অনুযায়ী, প্রতিটি বইয়ের এন্ট্রিগুলো ধারাবাহিকভাবে নম্বরযুক্ত হতে হবে। এই নম্বরগুলো প্রতি বছর নতুন করে শুরু হয় এবং বছরের শেষে শেষ হয়। তাই, আপনি প্রতিটি বছরের জন্য আলাদাভাবে নম্বরের একটি ক্রম দেখতে পাবেন।
law_reference: The Registration Act, 1908, Part XI, Section 53

question: What does this law say about keeping track of documents registered?
answer: Section 54 of The Registration Act, 1908 requires that every registering officer maintains current indexes detailing the contents of the registration books. These indexes should be updated as soon as possible after the officer has recorded a document's details. This helps in easily locating registered documents.
law_reference: The Registration Act, 1908, Part XI, Section 54

In every office in which any of the books hereinbefore mentioned are kept, there shall be prepared current indexes of the contents of such books; and every entry in such indexes shall be made, so far as practicable, immediately after the registering officer has copied, on field a memorandum of, the document to which it relates.

question: যদি আমি কোনো নিবন্ধিত দলিল খুঁজে পেতে সমস্যা হই, তাহলে এই আইন কিভাবে সাহায্য করবে?
answer: ধারা ৫৪, নিবন্ধন আইন, ১৯০৮ অনুযায়ী, প্রতিটি নিবন্ধক অফিসে নিবন্ধিত বইগুলির বিষয়বস্তু বিস্তারিতভাবে উল্লেখ করে 'চলমান সূচী' তৈরি এবং রক্ষণাবেক্ষণ করতে হবে। এই সূচীগুলি একটি ক্যাটালগের মতো কাজ করে, যেখানে নিবন্ধিত সমস্ত নথির তালিকা থাকে। নিবন্ধিত হওয়ার কাছাকাছি সময়ে এই সূচীগুলি আপডেট করা উচিত, যা আপনাকে প্রয়োজনীয় দলিল খুঁজে পেতে সাহায্য করবে।

question: What are the different types of indexes that must be kept at registration offices, and what information do they contain?
answer: According to Section 55 of The Registration Act, 1908, there are four indexes (Index No. I, II, III, and IV) that registering officers must maintain. Index No. I tracks the individuals involved in documents registered in Book No. 1. Index No. II contains details as directed by the Inspector-General. Index No. III specifically records information about wills and authorities in Book No. 3, along with executors and beneficiaries. Finally, Index No. IV records details related to documents registered in Book No. 4. Each index can also contain other particulars as instructed by the Inspector-General.

question: রেজিস্ট্রি অফিসে কী কী ধরনের ইন্ডেক্স (index) রাখা হয় এবং সেগুলোতে কী তথ্য থাকে?
answer: রেজিস্ট্রেশন আইন, ১৯০৮ এর ধারা ৫৫ অনুযায়ী, রেজিস্ট্রি অফিসে চারটি ভিন্ন ধরনের ইন্ডেক্স রাখা হয়: ইন্ডেক্স নং ১, ২, ৩ এবং ৪। ইন্ডেক্স নং ১-এ বই নং ১-এ নথিভুক্ত হওয়া ব্যক্তিদের নাম ও তথ্য থাকে। ইন্ডেক্স নং ২-এ পরিদর্শক-জেনারেল (Inspector-General) কর্তৃক নির্দেশিত বিবরণ অন্তর্ভুক্ত থাকে। ইন্ডেক্স নং ৩ বিশেষভাবে বই নং ৩-এ থাকা উইল (will) এবং কর্তৃপক্ষের তথ্য লিপিবদ্ধ করে, সেই সাথে নির্বাহক (executor) এবং受益者の নামও উল্লেখ করে। সবশেষে, ইন্ডেক্স নং ৪ বই নং ৪-এ নথিভুক্ত হওয়া документовগুলোর বিবরণ লিপিবদ্ধ করে। পরিদর্শক-জেনারেলের নির্দেশনা অনুযায়ী প্রতিটি ইন্ডেক্সে অতিরিক্ত তথ্যও থাকতে পারে।

question: What information *must* be recorded on a document when I submit it for registration, and what happens if someone refuses to sign or acknowledge something?
answer: Section 58 of The Registration Act, 1908 outlines what needs to be recorded on documents submitted for registration. Primarily, it requires the signature of everyone who admits to signing the document. If someone admits the signature was made by their representative, agent, or assign, *their* signature must also be recorded. Additionally, if someone is examined in relation to the document according to the Act, their signature is also necessary.  Finally, any payment of money or delivery of goods made in front of the registering officer, or admissions of receiving payment, must also be noted. Importantly, if someone refuses to endorse the document (meaning they refuse to sign or acknowledge it), the registering officer *can still* register the document, but they will note this refusal on the document itself.

58. (1) On every document admitted to registration, other than a copy of a decree or order, or a copy sent to a registering officer under section 89, there shall be endorsed from time to time the following particulars namely:-
 
 
(a) the signature and addition of every person admitting the execution of the document, and, if such execution has been admitted by the representative, assign or agent of any person, the signature and addition of such representative, assign or agent;
 
 
(b) the signature and addition of every person examined in reference to such document under any of the provisions of this Act; and
 
 
(c) any payment of money or delivery of goods made in the presence of the registering officer in reference to the execution of the document, and any admission of receipt of consideration, in whole or in part, made in his presence in reference to such execution.
 
 
(2) If any person admitting the execution of a document refuses to endorse the same, the registering officer shall nevertheless register it, but shall at the same time endorse a note of such refusal.

question: যদি আমি কোনো দলিলের মাধ্যমে অর্থ লেনদেন করি, তাহলে রেজিস্ট্রেশন অফিসের কর্মকর্তা কী কী বিষয় নোট করে রাখবেন?
answer: রেজিস্ট্রেশন আইন, ১৯০৮ এর ধারা ৫৮ অনুযায়ী, যখন আপনি কোনো দলিলের মাধ্যমে অর্থ লেনদেন করেন, তখন রেজিস্ট্রেশন অফিসের কর্মকর্তা নিম্নলিখিত বিষয়গুলি নোট করে রাখবেন: প্রথমত, দলিলের সাথে স্বাক্ষর করেছেন এমন প্রত্যেক ব্যক্তির স্বাক্ষর। যদি স্বাক্ষরটি প্রতিনিধি, assignee বা এজেন্টের মাধ্যমে হয়ে থাকে, তবে তাদের স্বাক্ষরও নথিভুক্ত করতে হবে। দ্বিতীয়ত, যদি রেজিস্ট্রেশন অফিসের কর্মকর্তা এই সংক্রান্ত কোনো বিষয় নিয়ে পরীক্ষা করেন, তবে তার স্বাক্ষরও নেওয়া হবে। সবশেষে, যদি রেজিস্ট্রি অফিসের সামনে কোনো অর্থ প্রদান বা পণ্য সরবরাহ করা হয়ে থাকে, অথবা আংশিক অর্থ প্রদানের বিষয়টি স্বীকার করা হয়, তবে সেটিও নথিবদ্ধ করা হবে।

question: What does it mean when the law says a registering officer must 'affix the date and his signature' to an endorsement?
answer: Section 59 of The Registration Act, 1908, Part XI, requires the registering officer to physically write the date and sign each endorsement (changes or additions) made to a document in their presence on the same day, relating to the same document. This ensures a clear record of when the endorsement was made and confirms the officer's oversight of the change.  It’s essentially a formal way of verifying the endorsement's authenticity and timeline.

question: রেজিস্ট্রিং অফিসার কিভাবে একটি ডকুমেন্টের পরিবর্তনে স্বাক্ষর ও তারিখ যুক্ত করবেন? এটা কি শুধু একটি ডকুমেন্টের জন্যই প্রযোজ্য?

question: যদি আমি নিবন্ধনের জন্য একটি দলিল উপস্থাপন করি যা নিবন্ধিত কর্মকর্তার কাছে বোধগম্য নয়, তাহলে কী হবে? (Jodi ami nijogoner jonno ekati dalil uposthapon kori jayni nijogito okkaltar pase bodhomyo noy, tahole ki hobe?)
answer: নিবন্ধক আইন, ১৯০৮ এর ১১-তম অংশ এর ৬২ নং ধারা অনুযায়ী, যদি কোনো দলিল নিবন্ধিত কর্মকর্তার কাছে বোধগম্য না হয়, তাহলে দলিলের একটি অনুবাদ رسمی নথিতে লিখতে হবে। এই অনুবাদ এবং দলিলের একটি কপি (ধারা ১৯ অনুযায়ী প্রয়োজনীয়) নিবন্ধন অফিসে জমা দেওয়া হবে। এর মাধ্যমে নিশ্চিত করা হবে যে, দলিলটির বিষয়বস্তু নথিভুক্ত হয়েছে, এমনকি যদি নিবন্ধিত কর্মকর্তা মূল ভাষা বুঝতে না পারেন। (Nibhog Ain, 1908 er ele-tom bhag er 62 no shara onujayi, jodi kono dalil nijogito okkaltar pase bodhomyo na hoy, tahole daliler ekati anubod rokmi nothite likhte hobe. Ei anubod ebong daliler ekati kopi (dhara 19 onujayi proyojon) nijogito office joma dewa hobe. Er mamle anumochito hobe je, dalil tiri bishoybosto nothibok hoche, ebong nijogito okkaltar mul bhasha bujhte na par.)

question: If a registering officer asks me to make a statement under this Act, can they force me to swear an oath?
answer: No, they cannot force you. Section 63(1) of The Registration Act, 1908 states that a registering officer *may* administer an oath to you if they are examining you under the Act, but it’s entirely at their discretion. You are not obligated to take the oath.
law_reference: The Registration Act, 1908, Part XI, Section 63
input_context:
63. (1) Every registering officer may at his discretion administer an oath to any person examined by him under the provisions of this Act.
 
 
(2) Every such officer may also at his discretion record a note of the substance of the statement made by each such person, and such statement shall be read over, or (if made in a language with which such person is not acquainted) interpreted to him in a language with which he is acquainted, and, if he admits the correctness of such note, it shall be signed by the registering officer.
 
 
(3) Every such note so signed shall be admissible for the purpose of proving that the statements therein recorded were made by the persons and under the circumstances therein stated.

question: What happens if I make a statement to a registering officer, and it’s written down? Do I have to agree with what’s written?
answer: Section 63(2) allows the registering officer to record a note of your statement. This note will be read to you, or interpreted in a language you understand if necessary. If you confirm the note accurately reflects your statement, the officer will sign it. You don't *have* to agree, but if you don't, it might affect how the statement is used later.

question: If I submit a document for registration, but the registering officer thinks the declared value is too low, what will happen?
answer: According to Section 63A of The Registration Act, 1908, if the registering officer believes the value declared on a document is lower than what's considered the market value, they can require you to pay the correct duties and fees before they register the document. This ensures the government receives the appropriate amount of revenue.
law_reference: The Registration Act, 1908, Part XI, Section 63A
input_context:
63A. (1) Notwithstanding anything contained in this Act or in any other law for the time being in force, where it appears to the registering officer that the value of any document presented for registration is less than the market value determined in the policy made under section 69, the registering officer shall, for the purpose of realising proper duties and other fees, require the presentant to submit the duties and fees so required and after realising such duties and fees, he shall register the said document.
 
 
(2) Where it is found upon inspection or otherwise that by non-compliance of the provision of sub-section (1), a document has been registered by a registering officer with improper duties and fees, such non-compliance of the said registering officer shall be deemed to be misconduct and the unpaid amount of duties and fees shall be realised from the concerned registering officer.

question: What happens if a registering officer registers a document with incorrect duties and fees because they didn't properly assess the value?
answer: Section 63A(2) states that if a registering officer registers a document with incorrect duties and fees because they didn't follow the procedure of assessing the value (as outlined in Section 63A(1)), this will be considered misconduct. Furthermore, the amount of duties and fees that should have been paid will be recovered from that registering officer.

answer: রেজিস্ট্রেশন অ্যাক্ট ১৯০৮ এর ৬৩এ ধারা অনুযায়ী, যদি রেজিস্ট্রি অফিসার মনে করেন যে নথিপত্রের declared value বাজারের নির্ধারিত মূল্যের চেয়ে কম, তাহলে তিনি আপনাকে অতিরিক্ত Duties এবং Fees পরিশোধ করতে বলতে পারেন। এর পরে তিনি নথিপত্রটি রেজিস্ট্রি করবেন। এটি নিশ্চিত করে যে সরকার সঠিক পরিমাণ রাজস্ব পাচ্ছে।

question: I own a property that has land in two different sub-districts. What happens when I register a document related to this property?
answer: According to Section 64 of The Registration Act, 1908, when you register a document relating to a property that's not entirely within a single sub-district, the Sub-Registrar who registers it must send a memorandum (a summary) of the registration, along with any endorsements or certificates, to all other Sub-Registrars under the same Registrar whose sub-districts contain parts of the property. These other Sub-Registrars then have to file this memorandum in their 'Book No. 1'. This ensures everyone aware of the registration affecting properties within their jurisdiction.
law_reference: The Registration Act, 1908, Part XI, Section 64
input_context: 64. Every Sub-Registrar on registering a non-testamentary document relating to immoveable property not wholly situate in his own sub-district shall make a memorandum thereof and of the endorsement and certificate (if any) thereon, and send the same to every other Sub-Registrar subordinate to the same Registrar as himself in whose sub-district any part of such property in situate, and such Sub-Registrar shall file the memorandum in his Book No. 1.

question: What is 'Book No. 1' mentioned in Section 64, and why is it important?
answer: Section 64 of The Registration Act, 1908 refers to 'Book No. 1' which is a specific record book kept by each Sub-Registrar. When a document is registered relating to property in multiple sub-districts, the other Sub-Registrars (those whose areas are affected by the registration) must file the memorandum (summary) of the registration in this book. This serves to inform them of the registered transactions affecting properties within their areas of responsibility, keeping everyone informed.
