question: আমার একটি সম্পত্তি আছে যার অংশ বিভিন্ন সাব-ডিস্ট্রিক্টে অবস্থিত। আমি যখন এই সম্পত্তির সাথে সম্পর্কিত কোনো দলিল রেজিস্ট্রি করব, তখন কি হবে?
answer: রেজিস্ট্রেশন আইন, ১৯০৮ এর ধারা ৬৪ অনুযায়ী, যদি আপনি এমন একটি দলিল রেজিস্ট্রি করেন যা সম্পূর্ণভাবে একটি সাব-ডিস্ট্রিক্টের মধ্যে অবস্থিত নয়, তাহলে যে সাব-রেজিস্ট্রার এটি রেজিস্ট্রি করবেন, তাকে অন্যান্য সমস্ত সাব-রেজিস্ট্রারের কাছে একটি মেমোরাન્ડাম (সারসংক্ষেপ) পাঠাতে হবে। যে সাব-ডিস্ট্রিক্টগুলোতে সম্পত্তির অংশ অবস্থিত, সেই এলাকার সাব-রেজিস্ট্রারদের কাছে পাঠাতে হবে। এই অন্যান্য সাব-রেজিস্ট্রাররা তাদের ‘বুক নং ১’-এ এই মেমোরাণ্ডাম ফাইল করতে হবে। এর মাধ্যমে নিশ্চিত করা হয় যে, সম্পত্তি সংক্রান্ত রেজিস্ট্রি কার্যক্রম সম্পর্কে সকলে অবগত।

question: My property is located in two different districts. What happens after a document related to it is registered?
answer: According to Section 65 of The Registration Act, 1908, if a document relates to property in more than one district, the Sub-Registrar who registers it must send a copy of the document, any endorsements or certificates, and a copy of the map (if there is one) to the Registrar of *each* district where the property is located (excluding the district where the Sub-Registrar’s office is). The Registrar then files these copies and sends a summary (memorandum) to the Sub-Registrars in those districts, who also file it. This ensures that all relevant authorities are aware of the transaction.

(2) The Registrar on receiving the same shall file in his Book No. 1 the copy of the document and the copy of the map or plan (if any), and shall forward a memorandum of the document to each of the Sub-registrars subordinate to him within whose sub-district any part of such property is situate: and every Sub-Registrar receiving such memorandum shall file it in his Book No. 1.

question: If a property is spread across multiple districts, who needs to keep records of the registration document?
answer: Section 65 of The Registration Act, 1908 dictates that multiple parties must keep records. The Registrar files these copies and forwards a 'memorandum' (summary) to the Sub-Registrars in each of those districts, who also file it. So, all relevant Sub-Registrars and Registrars are informed and keep records.

question: আমার একটি জমি একাধিক জেলায় বিস্তৃত। রেজিস্ট্রেশন করার পরে কী ঘটে?
answer: রেজিস্ট্রেশন অ্যাক্ট, ১৯০৮ এর ধারা ৬৫ অনুযায়ী, যদি কোনও দলিল একাধিক জেলায় অবস্থিত সম্পত্তির সাথে সম্পর্কিত হয়, তাহলে এটি রেজিস্টার করা সাব-রেজিস্ট্রারকে অবশ্যই সংশ্লিষ্ট প্রতিটি জেলার রেজিস্টারের কাছে দলিলের একটি কপি, কোনও প্রস্তাবনা বা শংসাপত্র এবং ম্যাপের (যদি থাকে) একটি কপি পাঠাতে হবে। রেজিস্টার তখন এই কপিগুলি সংরক্ষণ করবেন এবং সংশ্লিষ্ট সাব-রেজিস্টারদের কাছে একটি সারসংক্ষেপ (মেমোরাન્ડাম) পাঠাবেন, যারা এটিও সংরক্ষণ করবেন। এর মাধ্যমে লেনদেন সম্পর্কে সমস্ত প্রাসঙ্গিক কর্তৃপক্ষের জ্ঞান থাকে।

question: After a property document is registered, where does the Registrar send information about it, and why?
answer: Section 66 of The Registration Act, 1908 states that after registering a document relating to land, the Registrar must send a memorandum (a summary) to each Sub-Registrar whose area includes any part of the property. They also send a copy of the document and any included map to other Registrars in the district. This is done to ensure all relevant authorities are aware of the transaction and to maintain a complete record of property ownership across the region. Essentially, it keeps everyone informed.

question: জমির দলিল নিবন্ধনের পর, নিবন্ধিত কর্মকর্তার কী করতে হয়? (What does the registering officer have to do after registering a land document?)
answer: ভূমি দলিল নিবন্ধনের পর, নিবন্ধিত কর্মকর্তা (Registering Officer) согласно ধারা ৬৬, ১৯০৮ সালের নিবন্ধন আইন অনুযায়ী, নিবন্ধিত দলিলের একটি সারসংক্ষেপ (memorandum) তার অধীনস্থ প্রতিটি সাব-রেজিস্ট্রারের কাছে পাঠাতে হবে, যাদের এলাকার মধ্যে দলিলের কোনো অংশ অবস্থিত। এছাড়াও, তিনি দলিলের একটি কপি এবং যদি কোনো মানচিত্র থাকে তবে সেটিও অন্যান্য রেজিস্টারের কাছে পাঠাতে হবে, যাদের জেলার মধ্যে দলিলের কোনো অংশ অবস্থিত। (According to Section 66 of The Registration Act, 1908, after registering a land document, the registering officer must send a summary (memorandum) to each subordinate Sub-Registrar whose area includes any part of the document. Additionally, he must also send a copy of the document and any map, if any, to other Registrars whose district includes any part of the document.)
law_reference: The Registration Act, 1908, Part XI, Section 66
input_context:
66. (1) On registering any non-testamentary document relating to immoveable property the Registrar shall forward a memorandum of such document to each Sub-Registrar subordinate to himself in whose sub-district any part of the property is situate.
 
 
(2) The Registrar shall also forward a copy of such document, together with a copy of the map or plan (if any) mentioned in section 21, to every other Registrar in whose district any part of such property is situate.
 
 
(3) Such Registrar on receiving any such copy shall file it in his Book No. 1, and shall also send a memorandum of the copy to each of the Sub-Registrars subordinate to him within whose sub-district any part of the property is situate.
 
 
(4) Every Sub-Registrar receiving any memorandum under this section shall file it in his Book No. 1.

question: I'm confused. Does this mean the person in charge of my local land registration office has to follow instructions from a higher-up?
answer: Yes, it does. Section 68(1) of The Registration Act, 1908 states that every Sub-Registrar (the person typically handling registrations at the local office) works under the superintendence and control of the Registrar. This means the Registrar, who is in charge of the entire district, oversees their work and ensures they're following the law.
law_reference: The Registration Act, 1908, Part XI, Section 68
input_context:
68. (1) Every Sub-Registrar shall perform the duties of his office under the superintendence and control of the Registrar in whose district the office of such Sub-Registrar is situate.

question: If I find a mistake in my land registration documents, can the Registrar fix it?
answer: Absolutely. Section 68(2) gives the Registrar the power to issue orders to correct any errors, whether they arise from a complaint or otherwise. This includes errors in the registration books or office records. The Registrar's decision needs to be in accordance with the Act.

question: একজন সাব-রেজিস্ট্রার কিভাবে কাজ করবেন? তার কাজের ওপর কারো নজরদারি থাকবে কি?
answer: সাব-রেজিস্ট্রারগণ তাদের জেলার রেজিস্ট্রারের তত্ত্বাবধানে এবং নিয়ন্ত্রণেই কাজ করবেন। রেজিস্ট্রেশন আইন, ১৯০৮ এর ৬8(১) ধারায় এটি বলা হয়েছে। এর মানে হলো, জেলার রেজিস্ট্রারের নির্দেশ অনুযায়ী সাব-রেজিস্ট্রার কাজ করবেন এবং তিনি তাদের কাজের দেখভাল করবেন।
law_reference: The Registration Act, 1908, Part XI, Section 68
input_context:
68. (1) Every Sub-Registrar shall perform the duties of his office under the superintendence and control of the Registrar in whose district the office of such Sub-Registrar is situate.

question: Can the Inspector-General change the languages that are accepted for official documents at registration offices in different districts?
answer: Yes, according to Section 69 of The Registration Act, 1908, the Inspector-General has the power to declare what languages are considered commonly used in each district. This means they can decide which languages are officially accepted for registration documents in different areas of Bangladesh. These declarations are made through rules that must be approved by the government.
law_reference: The Registration Act, 1908, Part XI, Section 69

question: What happens after the Inspector-General makes new rules for registration offices?
answer: According to Section 69(2) of The Registration Act, 1908, the rules created by the Inspector-General must first be approved by the Government. Once approved, they are published in the official Gazette. After publication, these rules become legally effective, essentially acting as if they were directly written into the Act itself.
law_reference: The Registration Act, 1908, Part XI, Section 69

question: রেজিস্ট্রি অফিসে ছুটিগুলো কিভাবে নির্ধারিত হয়? (How are holidays determined in the registration offices?)
answer: According to Section 69 of The Registration Act, 1908, the Inspector-General has the power to determine and declare the holidays that will be observed in the registration offices. This is done through rules that must be approved by the Government and then published in the official Gazette to become legally effective.
law_reference: The Registration Act, 1908, Part XI, Section 69

question: I understand I may have been fined for an incorrect registration fee. Can the Inspector-General reduce or eliminate that fine?
answer: Yes, under Section 70 of The Registration Act, 1908, the Inspector-General has the power to reduce or completely remove the extra fine you paid if there was a difference between the fine levied under sections 25 or 34 and the proper registration fee. This is at the Inspector-General's discretion, meaning they will consider your case before making a decision.
law_reference: The Registration Act, 1908, Part XI, Section 70
input_context: 70. The Inspector-General may also, in the exercise of his discretion, remit wholly or in part the difference between any fine levied under section 25 or section 34, and the amount of the proper registration fee.

question: What exactly does 'proper registration fee' mean in relation to this section?
answer: Section 70 refers to the 'proper registration fee,' which is the legally correct amount that should have been paid for registration. If a fine was imposed due to a difference between the amount paid and this 'proper registration fee,' the Inspector-General can potentially reduce or waive the fine. It is up to the Inspector General to consider the circumstances to ensure the fine levied is appropriate.
law_reference: The Registration Act, 1908, Part XI, Section 70

question: আমি কিভাবে জানতে পারি যে আমার বেশি ফি দেওয়ার কারণে কোনো জরিমানা করা হয়েছে কিনা, এবং যদি জরিমানা হয়ে থাকে, তাহলে কিভাবে Inspector-General এর কাছে আপিল করতে পারি?
answer: যদি আপনি মনে করেন যে অতিরিক্ত ফি দেওয়ার কারণে আপনাকে জরিমানা করা হয়েছে, তাহলে বুঝতে পারবেন যে আপনার পরিশোধ করা ফি এবং সঠিক রেজিস্ট্রেশন ফি-এর মধ্যে পার্থক্য রয়েছে।  ধারা ৭০ এর অধীনে, Inspector-General তার বিবেচনার ভিত্তিতে ধারা ২৫ বা ৩৪ এর অধীনে আরোপিত জরিমানার সম্পূর্ণ বা আংশিক পরিমাণ কমাতে পারেন।  আপিল করার জন্য, আপনাকে সম্ভবত Inspector-General এর অফিসে একটি লিখিত আবেদন জমা দিতে হবে, যেখানে আপনার পরিস্থিতি ব্যাখ্যা করবেন এবং জরিমানার বিষয়টি বিবেচনার জন্য অনুরোধ করবেন।
law_reference: The Registration Act, 1908, Part XI, Section 70
input_context: 70. The Inspector-General may also, in the exercise of his discretion, remit wholly or in part the difference between any fine levied under section 25 or section 34, and the amount of the proper registration fee.

question: Where does this rule about copying documents by photography actually apply?
answer: Section 70A of The Registration Act, 1908 states that this part of the law – dealing with copying documents using photography – only applies to areas specifically mentioned in a notification issued under Section 70-D.  Essentially, it’s not a nationwide rule; it's limited to places that the government has officially designated.

question: I want to photograph a document for registration purposes. Does this mean I can do it anywhere in Bangladesh?
answer: No, Section 70A clarifies that you can only use photography to copy documents for registration in areas specifically listed in a notification issued under Section 70-D.  You'll need to check if the area where you are registering the document is one of those designated locations.
law_reference: The Registration Act, 1908, Part XI-A, Section 70A

question: আমি একটি দলিল আলোকচিত্রের মাধ্যমে প্রতিলিপি করতে চাই। এটি কোথায় প্রযোজ্য?
answer: ধারা ৭০এ অনুযায়ী, আলোকচিত্রের মাধ্যমে দলিল প্রতিলিপি করার নিয়মটি শুধুমাত্র সেইসব এলাকাগুলোতে প্রযোজ্য, যেগুলো ধারা ৭০-ডি এর অধীনে জারিকৃত বিজ্ঞপ্তিতে উল্লেখিত আছে। আপনার দলিলটি যে এলাকায় রেজিস্ট্রি করছেন, সেটি সেই এলাকাগুলোর মধ্যে আছে কিনা, তা আপনাকে নিশ্চিত করতে হবে।
law_reference: The Registration Act, 1908, Part XI-A, Section 70A
input_context: 70A. This Part shall apply to such areas only as are specified in a notification issued under section 70-D.

question: What does the term 'Photo-Registrar' mean in relation to document registration?
answer: Section 70B of The Registration Act, 1908 defines 'Photo-Registrar' as someone specifically appointed to handle document registration under this particular part of the Act, which deals with using photography to copy documents. Essentially, it refers to a designated official.

answer: Section 70B doesn’t explicitly state if a 'Photo-Registrar' is the same as a regular Sub-Registrar. question: ফটোগ্রাফির মাধ্যমে দলিল তৈরির ক্ষেত্রে ‘ফটো-রেজিস্ট্রার’ কী?
answer: রেজিস্ট্রেশন আইন, ১৯০৮ এর ধারা ৭০বি অনুযায়ী, ‘ফটো-রেজিস্ট্রার’ হলেন সেই ব্যক্তি যিনি এই আইনের একটি নির্দিষ্ট অংশের অধীনে ফটোগ্রাফির মাধ্যমে দলিল তৈরির জন্য নিযুক্ত হন। এর মানে হল, এই বিশেষ কাজটি করার জন্য একজন নির্দিষ্ট কর্মকর্তা রয়েছেন।

question: photographed documents এর জন্য রেজিস্টার নিয়োগের ক্ষমতা সরকারের আছে? সরকারের এই ক্ষমতা অন্য কাউকে দেওয়া যায় কিনা?
answer: হ্যাঁ, সরকার photographed documents (ফটোগ্রাফ করা নথি) এর জন্য রেজিস্টার নিয়োগ করতে পারে। Section 70C অনুসারে, সরকার কোনো রেজিস্টার, সাব-রেজিস্টার অথবা অন্য কোনো ব্যক্তিকে ফটোগ্রাফ-রেজিস্টার হিসেবে নিয়োগ করতে পারে। তবে, সরকার চাইলে ইন্সপেক্টর-জেনারেল অফ রেজিস্ট্রেশন-কে এই নিয়োগের ক্ষমতা দিতে পারে, তবে কিছু শর্ত এবং বিধিনিষেধ সাপেক্ষে।

question: I heard the government can photograph documents at registration offices. Why would they do that, and where would I know if this applies to my area?
answer: Section 70D of The Registration Act, 1908 allows the government to direct that copies of registered documents be made using photography in specific districts or sub-districts. They do this to streamline the registration process and potentially create more accessible records. To find out if this applies to your area, the government will publish a notification in the official Gazette. They will also post translated versions of the notification in a clear, visible place at the relevant registration offices.
law_reference: The Registration Act, 1908, Part XI-A, Section 70D

70D. (1) The Government may, by notification in the official Gazette, direct that in any district or sub-district specified in the notification copies of documents admitted to registration under this Act shall be made by means of Photography.
 
 
(2) On the issue of such notification it shall be translated into Bengali and shall be posted in a conspicuous place at the registration offices affected by the notification.

question: If my local registration office is using photography to copy documents, does that mean they have to put up a notice about it?

question: அதிகாரப்பூர்வ গেজেটে বিজ্ঞপ্তি প্রকাশের পর, ফটোগ্রাফি করার নিয়ম কার্যকর হবে? আমার এলাকায় ফটোগ্রাফি করা হবে কিনা কিভাবে জানতে পারবো?
answer: হ্যাঁ, ফটোগ্রাফি করার নিয়ম কার্যকর হবে যখন সরকার অফিশিয়াল গেজেটে বিজ্ঞপ্তি প্রকাশ করবে। বিজ্ঞপ্তিটি প্রথমে ইংরেজিতে প্রকাশ করা হবে, তারপর বাংলাতেও অনুবাদ করে প্রকাশ করা হবে। আপনার এলাকায় ফটোগ্রাফি করা হবে কিনা তা জানতে, আপনাকে অফিশিয়াল গেজেট দেখতে হবে অথবা স্থানীয় রেজিস্ট্রেশন অফিসে গিয়ে নোটিশ বোর্ড দেখে নিশ্চিত হতে হবে।
law_reference: The Registration Act, 1908, Part XI-A, Section 70D

70D. (1) The Government may, by notification in the official Gazette, direct that in any district or sub-district specified in the notification copies of documents admitted to registration under this Act shall be made by means of Photography.

question: I'm taking a document for registration in an area that has been notified under section 70-D. What exactly needs to be done to the document before it's registered?
answer: Section 70E(1)(a) states that every document presented for registration (either under section 35 or 41) must be signed in the presence of the registering officer by the person presenting it.  It also needs to be carefully marked with an identification stamp and its serial number. This is done to ensure proper tracking and photographic record-keeping.
law_reference: The Registration Act, 1908, Part XI-A, Section 70E
input_context:
70E. In any district or sub-district in respect of which a notification has been issued under section 70-D, the provisions of this Act shall, for the purposes of this Part, be subject to the following modifications, namely:-
 
 
(1) (a) Every document admitted to registration under section 35 or section 41 shall on every page-
 
 
(i) be signed in the presence of the registering officer by the person or anyone of the persons presenting the document for registration; and
 
 
(ii) be carefully marked with an identification stamp and the serial number of the document.
 
 
(b) It shall then be transmitted by the registering officer, unless he is himself the Photo-Registrar, to the Photo-Registrar, and the registering officer or the Photo-Registrar, as the case may be, shall cause each side of each page of such document together with all stamps, endorsements, seals, signatures, thumb-impressions and certificates appearing thereon to be photographed without subtraction or alteration. He may for this purpose cut or untie, without breaking any seals, the thread or ribbon, if any, wherewith the pages of the document are sewn together, in order to separate the pages of the document, and, as soon as the document has been photographed, he shall, as far as practicable, exactly rebind the document as before, and, if he has cut the thread or ribbon shall seal it over the joint with his seal:
 
 
Provided that the party presenting the document for registration shall, if he so desires, be allowed to be present and watch the unbinding, rebinding and sealing of the document:
 
 
Provided further that if the party presenting the document so requests the document shall be returned to him unbound:
 
 
Provided also that before or after transmission of the document to the Photo-Registrar the party presenting the document may require the registering officer to have it copied by hand under section 52, or if the document has been presented for registration under section 19 its translation copied under section 62 on payment of an additional copying fee.
 
 
(c) There shall then be prepared and preserved the negative and at least one Photographic print and to each such negative and print the Photo-Registrar shall fix his signature and seal in token of the exact correspondence of the copy to the original document, as admitted for registration:

question: If a Sub-Registrar denies registering my document, what should they do?
answer: According to Section 71 of The Registration Act, 1908, if a Sub-Registrar refuses to register a document (unless it's because the property isn't in their area), they must write down their reasons for refusal in a specific book (Book No. 2) and mark the document as 'registration refused.' They're also required to give you a copy of those written reasons if you ask for it, and without unreasonable delay.

(2) No registering officer shall accept for registration a document so endorsed unless and until, under the provisions hereinafter contained, the document is directed to be registered.

question: I went to register a document, but the Sub-Registrar refused. Can I appeal this decision? What if the refusal wasn’t because they claimed the document wasn’t valid?
answer: Yes, you can appeal. Section 72 of The Registration Act, 1908 states that if a Sub-Registrar refuses to register a document (whether it’s compulsory or optional registration) for any reason *other than* claiming the document isn't valid (denial of execution), you have the right to appeal to the Registrar who is above the Sub-Registrar in the hierarchy. You must file the appeal within 30 days from the date the Sub-Registrar made the refusal order. The Registrar can then decide to either uphold the Sub-Registrar's decision or change it.
law_reference: The Registration Act, 1908, Part XII, Section 72
input_context:

(2) If the order of the Registrar directs the document to be registered and the document is duly presented for registration within thirty days after the making of such order, the Sub-Registrar shall obey the same, and thereupon shall, so far as may be practicable, follow the procedure prescribed in sections 58, 59 and 60; and such registration shall take effect as if the document had been registered when it was first duly presented for registration.

They should then follow the procedures outlined in sections 58, 59, and 60 as much as possible. Importantly, the registration will be treated as if the document had been registered from the very first time you submitted it for registration.

question: যদি কোনো সাব-রেজিস্ট্রার দলিল প্রত্যাখ্যান করেন কারণ যিনি এটিতে স্বাক্ষর করেছেন তিনি স্বাক্ষর অস্বীকার করেন, তাহলে আমি কী করতে পারি?
answer: রেজিস্ট্রেশন আইন, ১৯০৮ এর ধারা ৭৩ আপনাকে সাব-রেজিস্ট্রারের সিদ্ধান্তকে আপিল করার অনুমতি দেয়। আপনি আপিল করার জন্য refusals order হওয়ার তারিখ থেকে ৩০ দিনের মধ্যে রেজিস্ট্রারের কাছে আবেদন করতে পারেন (সাব-রেজিস্ট্রারের ঊর্ধ্বতন কর্মকর্তা)। আপনি মূলত রেজিস্টারকে পরিস্থিতি পর্যালোচনা করতে এবং নির্ধারণ করতে বলছেন যে স্বাক্ষর অস্বীকারেরdespite আপনার দলিল নিবন্ধিত করার অধিকার এখনও আছে কিনা।

question: If a document is presented to a Registrar for registration and there's a dispute about its validity, what does the Registrar do?
answer: According to Section 74 of The Registration Act, 1908, Part XII, the Registrar is required to investigate. They will first check if the document has actually been signed and executed. Then, they're obligated to confirm that all legal requirements for registration have been met by the person presenting the document. This ensures the document is eligible for registration.
law_reference: The Registration Act, 1908, Part XII, Section 74

question: What are the two main things a Registrar must check when someone applies to register a document and there's a question about whether it can be registered?
answer: Section 74 of The Registration Act, 1908, Part XII, dictates that the Registrar must verify two essential things. First, they must confirm that the document has been properly signed and executed. Second, they must ensure that all the necessary legal conditions for registration have been fulfilled by the person bringing the document to the Registrar.
law_reference: The Registration Act, 1908, Part XII, Section 74

question: রেজিস্ট্রি অফিসে একটি দলিল নিবন্ধনের জন্য উপস্থাপন করা হলে এবং সেখানে দলিলের বৈধতা নিয়ে প্রশ্ন উঠলে, রেজিস্টার কিভাবে কাজ করেন?
answer: রেজিস্ট্রি আইন, ১৯০৮ এর ১২ অংশ, ৭৪ ধারা অনুযায়ী, রেজিস্টারকে প্রথমে যাচাই করতে হবে যে দলিলটি সঠিকভাবে স্বাক্ষরিত ও সম্পাদিত হয়েছে কিনা। এরপর, নিবন্ধনের জন্য প্রয়োজনীয় আইনগত শর্তগুলো পূরণ হয়েছে কিনা, সেটি দেখতে হবে। এর মাধ্যমে দলিলটি নিবন্ধনের যোগ্য কিনা, তা নিশ্চিত করা হয়।

question: If the Registrar believes a document is valid after reviewing it, what happens next?
answer: According to Section 75 of The Registration Act, 1908, if the Registrar finds the document was properly executed and all requirements are met, they *must* order the document to be registered.  The registering officer then needs to register the document as soon as possible, following procedures similar to those described in sections 58, 59, and 60 of the Act.
law_reference: The Registration Act, 1908, Part XII, Section 75
input_context:
75. (1) If the Registrar finds that the document had been executed and that the said requirements have been complied with, he shall order the document to be registered.
 
 
(2) If the document is duly presented for registration within thirty days after the making of such order, the registering officer shall obey the same and thereupon shall, so far as may be practicable, follow the procedure prescribed in sections 58, 59 and 60.
 
 
(3) Such registration shall take effect as if the document had been registered when it was first duly presented for registration.
 
 
(4) The Registrar may, for the purpose of any enquiry under section 74, summon and enforce the attendance of witnesses, and compel them to give evidence, as if he were a Civil Court, and he may also direct by whom the whole or any part of the costs of any such enquiry shall be paid, and such costs shall be recoverable as if they had been awarded in a suit under the Code of Civil Procedure, 1908.

question: How quickly does the registering officer need to register a document after the Registrar has ordered it?
answer: Section 75(2) of The Registration Act, 1908 states that the document must be presented for registration within thirty days after the Registrar's order. If it is presented within that timeframe, the registering officer *must* register it and follow the procedures outlined in sections 58, 59, and 60 as much as possible.

answer: রেজিস্ট্রেশন আইন, ১৯০৮ এর ধারা ৭৫ অনুযায়ী, যদি রেজিস্টার মনে করেন দলিলটি সঠিকভাবে সম্পাদন করা হয়েছে এবং সমস্ত শর্ত পূরণ হয়েছে, তবে তিনি দলিলটি নিবন্ধনের নির্দেশ দিতে বাধ্য। এরপর নিবন্ধক যত দ্রুত সম্ভব এবং সম্ভব হলে, ধারা ৫৮, ৫৯ এবং ৬০-এর মতো পদ্ধতি অনুসরণ করে দলিলটি নিবন্ধন করবেন।

question: If a Registrar refuses to register my document, what information must they provide me?
answer: According to Section 76 of The Registration Act, 1908, if a Registrar refuses to register your document, they must write down the reasons for their refusal in their official record book (Book No. 2).  You are entitled to request and receive a copy of these recorded reasons without any unnecessary delay. This ensures you understand why the registration was denied.
law_reference: The Registration Act, 1908, Part XII, Section 76
input_context:
76. (1) Every Registrar refusing-
 
 
(a) to register a document except on the ground that the property to which it relates is not situate within his district or that the document ought to be registered in the office of a Sub-Registrar, or
 
 
(b) to direct the registration of a document under section 72 or section 75,
 
 
shall make an order of refusal and record the reasons for such order in his Book No. 2, and, on application made by any person executing or claiming under the document, shall, without unnecessary delay, give him a copy of the reasons so recorded.
 
 
(2) No appeal lies from any order by a Registrar under this section or section 72.

question: Can I appeal if a Registrar refuses to register a document?
answer: No, you cannot appeal a Registrar's decision to refuse registration under Section 76 or Section 72 of The Registration Act, 1908. The law explicitly states that no appeal lies from orders made under these sections. This means you cannot take the case to a higher court for review.

question: যদি কোনো রেজিস্ট্রি আমার দলিল নথিভুক্ত করতে অস্বীকার করে, তাহলে তারা কী বলতে বাধ্য থাকবে?
answer: রেজিস্ট্রি আইন, ১৯০৮ এর ধারা ৭৬ অনুযায়ী, যদি কোনো রেজিস্ট্রি আপনার দলিল নথিভুক্ত করতে অস্বীকার করে, তাহলে তাদের অবশ্যই তাদের সিদ্ধান্তের কারণ একটি নির্দিষ্ট বইয়ে (বই নং ২) লিখতে হবে। আপনি সেই সিদ্ধান্তের কারণগুলোর একটি অনুলিপি পেতে অনুরোধ করতে পারেন এবং রেজিস্ট্রিকে তা দিতে হবে। এর মাধ্যমে আপনি বুঝতে পারবেন কেন আপনার দলিলটি নথিভুক্ত করা হয়নি।

question: If the Registrar refuses to register my document, how long do I have to take the matter to court?
answer: According to Section 77 of The Registration Act, 1908, you have thirty (30) days from the date the Registrar made the order refusing registration to file a lawsuit in a Civil Court. This lawsuit would ask the court to order the Registrar to register your document. Don’t worry, failing to file a suit or if it is dismissed, doesn't mean you lose other options available based on the unregistered document.
law_reference: The Registration Act, 1908, Part XII, Section 77
input_context:
77. (1) Where the Registrar refuses to order the document to be registered, under section 72 or section 76, any person claiming under such document, or his representative, assign or agent, may, within thirty days after the making of the order of refusal, institute in the Civil Court, within the local limits of whose original jurisdiction is situate the office in which the document is sought to be registered, a suit far a decree directing the document to be registered in such office if it be duly presented for registration within thirty days after the passing of such decree:
 
 
Provided that failure to file a suit or the dismissal of a suit filed under this section shall not disentitle a party to any other remedy to which he may be entitled, on the basis of the unregistered document.
 
 
(2) The provisions contained in sub-sections (2) and (3) of section 75 shall, mutatis mutandis, apply to all documents presented for registration in accordance with any such decree, and, notwithstanding anything contained in this Act, the document shall be receivable in evidence in such suit.

answer: রেজিস্ট্রি আইন, ১৯০৮ এর ধারা ৭৭ অনুসারে, রেজিস্টার আপনার দলিল নথিভুক্ত করতে অস্বীকার করলে, আপনি নথিভুক্ত হওয়ার দাবি করা ব্যক্তি বা আপনার প্রতিনিধি, অ্যাসিগনি বা এজেন্ট হিসেবে, সেই আদেশ জারির তারিখ থেকে ৩০ দিনের মধ্যে স্থানীয় দেওয়ানি আদালতে মামলা করতে পারেন। এই মামলাটি রেজিস্টার্ডকে আপনার দলিল নথিভুক্ত করার নির্দেশ দেওয়ার জন্য করা হবে। একটি বিষয় মনে রাখবেন, মামলা দায়ের না করা বা আদালত কর্তৃক মামলা বাতিল হয়ে গেলেও, আপনি unregistered document-এর ওপর ভিত্তি করে অন্যান্য আইনি প্রতিকার পেতে পারেন। (Registri Ain, 1908 er dhara 77 anuswara, registrar amar dolil nothivrutta akorho kore thakle, ami nothivrjotar dabri kara byaktirikne ba amar protinidhi, assigni ba agent hisebe, sei adesh jarir tarikh theke 30 diner moddhe jotokini deowani adalate kamal korte pare. question: How does the government decide how much I have to pay to register a property document?
answer: According to Section 78 of The Registration Act, 1908, the government creates a table that lists all the fees payable for various registration-related activities, including registering property documents. This table isn't fixed permanently; the government can update it as needed to ensure the Act's purposes are achieved.
law_reference: The Registration Act, 1908, Part XIII, Section 78

question: What kind of additional fees might I have to pay besides the basic registration fee?
answer: Section 78 outlines several extra or additional fees. These could include fees for things like registering documents under Section 30, obtaining commissions, filing translations (if documents are not in Bangla), having a registration official visit your private residence, ensuring the safe storage and return of your documents, or other administrative matters that the government deems necessary for the Registration Act to function effectively. The government publishes a table detailing these fees.
law_reference: The Registration Act, 1908, Part XIII, Section 78

question: আমি কীভাবে জানবো দলিল নিবন্ধনের জন্য সরকার কত টাকা নির্ধারণ করেছে?
answer: আইন অনুযায়ী, সরকার একটি তালিকা তৈরি করে, যেখানে দলিল নিবন্ধনের জন্য নির্ধারিত ফি উল্লেখ করা হয়। এই তালিকাটি সরকারের ওয়েবসাইটে অথবা নিবন্ধন অফিসের বিজ্ঞপ্তিতে পাওয়া যেতে পারে। এটি পরিবর্তনশীল, তাই সবসময় আপডেটেড তালিকা দেখা গুরুত্বপূর্ণ। এটি নিবন্ধন আইনের ধারা ৭১-এ বলা হয়েছে।
law_reference: The Registration Act, 1908, Part XIII, Section 78

question: I'm selling a property valued at 7 lakh taka. How much will I have to pay for registration?
answer: According to Section 78A of The Registration Act, 1908, Part XIII, since your property is valued above five lakh taka but not more than fifty lakh taka, the registration fee will be 1,000 taka.
law_reference: The Registration Act, 1908, Part XIII, Section 78A

question: My father is gifting me a property. We are both Muslims. How much will the registration cost?
answer: Section 78A(bb) states that if a Muslim property is gifted between specific relatives (like parents and children), the registration fee is 100 taka, regardless of the property's value.
law_reference: The Registration Act, 1908, Part XIII, Section 78A

question: আমি ২০ লাখ টাকার জন্য বন্ধক রেখেছি। নিবন্ধনের জন্য কত টাকা লাগবে?
answer: ধারা 78A এর (গ) অনুযায়ী, যেহেতু আপনি ২০ লাখ টাকার জন্য বন্ধক রেখেছেন, তাই নিবন্ধনের ফি হবে টাকার পরিমাণের ০.২৫% (শূন্য দশমিক ২৫ শতাংশ), তবে সর্বনিম্ন ১৫০০ টাকা এবং সর্বোচ্চ ২০০০ টাকা পর্যন্ত।
law_reference: The Registration Act, 1908, Part XIII, Section 78A

question: My family is dividing a piece of land worth 40 lakh taka. How much will it cost to register the partition document?
answer: According to Section 78B of The Registration Act, 1908, Part XIII, the registration fee for an instrument of partition when the property's valuation is above thirty lakh taka and not more than fifty lakh taka is eighteen hundred taka.  So, you're looking at a fee of 1800 taka.
law_reference: The Registration Act, 1908, Part XIII, Section 78B

question: If I'm registering a partition document, does this law override any other registration fees I might have been told about?
answer: Yes, Section 78B of The Registration Act, 1908, Part XIII, specifically states that it overrides anything contained in Section 78 or any other law currently in force regarding registration fees for instruments of partition. This means the fees outlined in this section apply, even if you're told something different elsewhere.
law_reference: The Registration Act, 1908, Part XIII, Section 78B

question: আমার পরিবারের একটি জমি রেজিস্ট্রেশন করার সময়, যদি জমির মূল্য ৭০ লক্ষ টাকা হয়, তাহলে রেজিস্ট্রেশন ফি কত হবে? (Amar poribarer ekti jomi registration korar somoy, jodi jomir mullo 70 lakho taka hoy, tahole registration fee koto hobe?)

question: I'm taking a property document for registration. When exactly do I need to pay the registration fees?

question: If I forget to bring the registration fee with me to the registration office, can I register the document at a later date?

question: What happens if I am wrongly accused of being a tout and my name appears on a published list?
answer: According to Section 80A of The Registration Act, 1908, you have the right to challenge the inclusion of your name on the list. You can apply in writing to the District Registrar within thirty days of the publication of the list where your name first appears, requesting its removal. The District Registrar will then conduct an inquiry (if deemed necessary) and their decision on your application will be final.
law_reference: The Registration Act, 1908, Part XIII-A, Section 80A
input_context:
80A. (1) Every Registrar of a district as regards his own office and the offices subordinate thereto and every sub-divisional magistrate as regards the registration offices within his own jurisdiction may frame and publish lists of persons proved to his satisfaction or to the satisfaction of any Sub-Registrar as provided in section 80B, by evidence of general repute or otherwise, habitually to act as touts, and may, from time to time, alter and amend such lists.
 
 
(2) No person's name shall be included in any such list until he shall have had an opportunity of showing cause against such inclusion.
 
 
(3) Where the name of any person is included in a list framed and published by a sub-divisional magistrate under this section, such person may, within thirty days of the publication of the list in which his name first appears, apply in writing to the Registrar of the district for the removal of his name from such list; and the orders of the Registrar passed after such inquiry (if any) as he considers necessary, on such application shall be final.

question: Who has the power to create these lists of touts?
answer: Section 80A of The Registration Act, 1908 states that the power to frame and publish lists of touts lies with two groups: firstly, the Registrar of a district for their own office and subordinate offices, and secondly, a sub-divisional magistrate for the registration offices within their jurisdiction.

question: If someone is suspected of being a tout, how does the Registration Act, 1908 handle the situation?
answer: Section 80B of The Registration Act, 1908 allows a Registrar or Sub-Divisional Magistrate to ask a Sub-Registrar to investigate someone suspected of being a tout. The Sub-Registrar will then hold an inquiry, giving the suspected person a chance to explain themselves (as outlined in sub-section (2) of section 80A).  Finally, the Sub-Registrar reports back to the original authority, stating whether they believe the person is a tout. If confirmed, the authority can add the person’s name to a public list of touts.
law_reference: The Registration Act, 1908, Part XIII-A, Section 80B

Any Registrar of a district of sub-divisional magistrate may send to any Sub-Registrar within the jurisdiction of such authority the name of any person alleged or suspected to be a tout, and request the Sub-Registrar to hold an enquiry in regard to such person; and the Sub-Registrar shall thereupon hold an enquiry into the conduct of that person and, after giving him an opportunity of showing cause as provided in sub-section (2) of section 80A, shall report to the authority who has made the request whether the person has been proved to the satisfaction of the Sub-Registrar to be a tout; and that authority may include the name of any person who has been so proved to be a tout in the list of touts framed and published by him under sub-section (1) of section 80A:

answer: যদি কাউকে দালাল হিসেবে সন্দেহ করা হয়, তাহলে রেজিস্ট্রেশন আইন, ১৯০৮ এর ধারা ৮০ বি অনুসারে, একজন রেজিস্ট্রার বা উপ-বিভাগীয় ম্যাজিস্ট্রেট একজন সাব-রেজিস্ট্রারকে ঐ ব্যক্তির বিরুদ্ধে তদন্ত শুরু করার জন্য অনুরোধ করতে পারেন। এরপর সাব-রেজিস্ট্রার একটি তদন্ত করবেন এবং ঐ ব্যক্তিকে তার স্বপক্ষে কথা বলার সুযোগ দেবেন (ধারা ৮০ এর উপধারা (২) অনুযায়ী)। সবশেষে, সাব-রেজিস্ট্রার যিনি তদন্তের অনুরোধ করেছিলেন সেই কর্তৃপক্ষের কাছে একটি প্রতিবেদন পেশ করবেন, যেখানে বলা হবে যে তারা ঐ ব্যক্তিকে দালাল হিসেবে প্রমাণ করতে পেরেছেন কিনা। যদি নিশ্চিত হওয়া যায়, তাহলে কর্তৃপক্ষ ঐ ব্যক্তির নাম দালালদের একটি সরকারি তালিকায় যোগ করতে পারে। (According to Section 80B of The Registration Act, 1908, a Registrar or Sub-Divisional Magistrate can request a Sub-Registrar to initiate an investigation against the person. question: I saw someone being told they couldn't enter the registration office. Can the registration officer just randomly ban people?
answer: No, the registration officer can't just ban anyone they feel like. According to Section 80D of The Registration Act, 1908, Part XIII-A, they can only exclude people who are listed on a specific list. The officer can create a general or special order to exclude those listed. This isn't an arbitrary power, but a measure to control access based on pre-defined lists.
law_reference: The Registration Act, 1908, Part XIII-A, Section 80D

question: What kind of list are we talking about here? Who decides who goes on it?
answer: Section 80D of The Registration Act, 1908, Part XIII-A, refers to a 'list'. The Act doesn't specify *who* creates or maintains this list, or the criteria for inclusion. It simply gives the registering officer the power to exclude anyone whose name is on such a list. question: আমি শুনেছি রেজিস্ট্রেশন অফিসে কিছু লোক প্রবেশ করতে পারছেন না। এই বিষয়ে আইন কী বলে?
answer: রেজিস্ট্রেশন অফিসে কারা প্রবেশ করতে পারবেন না, সে বিষয়ে আইন আছে। রেজিস্ট্রেশন অ্যাক্ট, ১৯০৮-এর ১৩-এ খণ্ড-এর ৮০ডি ধারা অনুযায়ী, কোনো রেজিস্টারিং অফিসার সাধারণ বা বিশেষ আদেশের মাধ্যমে তার রেজিস্ট্রেশন অফিসের এলাকা থেকে যে কোনো ব্যক্তিকে তালিকাভুক্ত করলে তাকে প্রবেশ করতে বাধা দিতে পারেন। তবে, এটি সম্পূর্ণভাবে অফিসারের ইচ্ছার উপর নির্ভর করে না, বরং একটি নির্দিষ্ট তালিকার উপর ভিত্তি করে।
law_reference: The Registration Act, 1908, Part XIII-A, Section 80D

question: I was previously told to stay away from the registration office. If I accidentally go back without written permission, will I be considered a tout?
answer: Yes, according to Section 80E of The Registration Act, 1908, if you’re excluded from a registration office under Section 80D and then found within its premises without written permission from the registering officer, you'll be considered a tout under Section 82A. However, there's an exception: this rule doesn't apply if you are a party to a document being registered or if you were instructed to appear by the Registering Officer.
law_reference: The Registration Act, 1908, Part XIII-A, Section 80E

Provided that this section shall not apply where such person is a party to a document intended for registration at such office or has been directed to appear by any process of Registering Officer.

question: What does it mean to be considered a 'tout' under this law, and what are the consequences?
answer: Section 80E of The Registration Act, 1908 deems a person found within a registration office without permission, after being previously excluded, to be acting as a 'tout.'  This means they are presumed to be soliciting business or influencing transactions related to registration. Section 82A outlines the consequences for touts, which can include fines and other penalties. It's best to avoid being in such a situation entirely.

question: আমি আগে রেজিস্ট্রেশন অফিসে প্রবেশ করতে নিষেধ করা হয়েছিল, কিন্তু জরুরি প্রয়োজনে ফিরে যেতে বাধ্য হলাম। সেক্ষেত্রে আমাকে কি দালাল হিসেবে গণ্য করা হবে?
answer: রেজিস্ট্রেশন আইন, ১৯০৮ এর ধারা ৮০ই অনুযায়ী, যদি আপনাকে আগে রেজিস্ট্রেশন অফিস থেকে বের করে দেওয়া হয়ে থাকে এবং আপনি লিখিত অনুমতি ব্যতীত সেখানে ফিরে আসেন, তবে আপনাকে দালাল হিসেবে গণ্য করা হতে পারে। তবে একটি ব্যতিক্রম রয়েছে: যদি আপনি রেজিস্ট্রেশনের জন্য কোনো দলিলের পক্ষ হন অথবা রেজিস্ট্রিং অফিসার কর্তৃক উপস্থিত হওয়ার নির্দেশ পান, তবে এই নিয়ম আপনার ক্ষেত্রে প্রযোজ্য হবে না।
law_reference: The Registration Act, 1908, Part XIII-A, Section 80E
input_context:
80E. Every person who having been excluded from the precincts of a registration office under section 80D is found within the precincts of any registration office without written permission from the registering officer shall be deemed to be acting as a tout for the purposes of section 82A.
 
 
Provided that this section shall not apply where such person is a party to a document intended for registration at such office or has been directed to appear by any process of Registering Officer.

question: If a tout is found in the registration office, can the registering officer order their arrest?
answer: Yes, according to Section 80F of The Registration Act, 1908, a registering officer can order the arrest of a tout found within the registration office through a written order.  The person arrested must then be brought before the registering officer immediately.
law_reference: The Registration Act, 1908, Part XIII-A, Section 80F
input_context:
80F. (1) Any registering officer may, by an order in writing, direct any person named in the order to arrest any such tout found within the precincts of the registration office. Such tout may be arrested accordingly and shall be forthwith produced before the registering officer.
 
 
(2) If the tout admits his offence the provisions of section 480 and 481 of the Code of Criminal Procedure, 1898, shall be applicable, so far as may be, to his detention, trial and punishment.
 
 
If the tout does not admit his offence the provisions of section 480 of the said Code shall be similarly applicable to his detention, trial and punishment.
 
 
(3) A registering officer shall be deemed to be a Civil Court for the purposes of sections 480, 481 and 482 of the said Code.

question: What happens to a tout who admits to being a tout?
answer: If a tout admits to their offense, Section 80F(2) of The Registration Act, 1908 states that the same rules used for detention, trial, and punishment outlined in sections 480 and 481 of the Code of Criminal Procedure, 1898 will apply to them.

question: I often see people outside the registration office offering to help with document writing. What happens if someone isn't licensed to write these documents, and are they considered illegal?
answer: Section 80G of The Registration Act, 1908 allows the Inspector-General to declare people writing documents outside of the registration office without a license as 'touts' for the purposes of this Act. This means they can be considered to be acting unlawfully and subject to penalties. The Inspector-General defines these conditions through rules, so it's important to check the latest regulations to understand exactly who is considered a tout.
law_reference: The Registration Act, 1908, Part XIII-B, Section 80G
input_context:
80G. (1) The Inspector-General shall have power from time to time, to make rules, consistent with this Act-
 
 
(a) prescribing the manner in which and the terms subject to which persons who write documents, outside the precincts of registration office, or who frequent the precincts of registration offices, for the purpose of writing documents, may be granted licences;
 
 
(b) prescribing the fees (if any) to be paid for such licences; and
 
 
(c) declaring the conditions under which persons who write documents outsides the precincts of registration offices without licences shall be deemed to be touts for the purposes of this Act.
 
 
(2) The rules so made shall be submitted to the Government for approval, and, after they have been approved they shall be published in the official Gazette and on publication shall have effect as if enacted in this Act.

question: আমি কিভাবে জানব একজন ব্যক্তি যিনি অফিসের বাইরে কাগজপত্র লিখে দিচ্ছেন, তার লাইসেন্স আছে কিনা? এই প্রক্রিয়াটি কী?
answer: রেজিস্ট্রেশন আইনের 80G ধারায় বলা হয়েছে, ইন্সপেক্টর জেনারেলকে কিছু নিয়ম তৈরি করার ক্ষমতা দেওয়া হয়েছে। এই নিয়মের মাধ্যমে অফিসের বাইরে যারা কাগজপত্র লিখে দেন, তাদের লাইসেন্স দেওয়া এবং এর শর্তাবলী নির্ধারণ করা হয়। ইন্সপেক্টর জেনারেল এই নিয়মগুলো সরকারের কাছে অনুমোদনের জন্য পাঠাবেন, এবং সরকারের অনুমোদন পাওয়ার পরে গেজেটে প্রকাশিত হবে। গেজেটে প্রকাশিত হওয়ার পরই এই নিয়মগুলো কার্যকর হবে।

question: What happens if a registration officer deliberately makes a mistake while registering a document, and that mistake harms someone?
answer: According to Section 81 of The Registration Act, 1908, if a registration officer or someone working in their office intentionally makes an incorrect endorsement, copy, translation, or registration of a document, and this error causes harm (as defined in the Penal Code) to another person, they can be imprisoned for up to seven years, fined, or both. The intention or likely consequence of causing injury is key to this penalty.
law_reference: The Registration Act, 1908, Part XIV, Section 81
input_context: 81. Every registering officer appointed under this Act and every person employed in his office for the purposes of this Act, who, being charged with the endorsing, copying, translating or registering of any document presented or deposited under its provisions, endorses, copies, translates or registers such document in a manner which he knows or believes to be incorrect, intending thereby to cause or knowing it to be likely that he may thereby cause, injury, as defined in the Penal Code, to any person, shall be punishable with imprisonment for a term which may extend to seven years, or with fine, or with both.

question: Could someone who assists a registration officer also be held responsible if a document is registered incorrectly and causes harm?
answer: Yes, Section 81 of The Registration Act, 1908 applies to anyone employed in a registration officer’s office who is involved in endorsing, copying, translating, or registering documents. If that person intentionally makes a mistake, knowing or believing it to be incorrect, and that mistake causes harm, they are subject to the same penalties – up to seven years imprisonment, a fine, or both.

question: যদি কোনো রেজিস্ট্রি অফিসার ইচ্ছাকৃতভাবে ভুল করে একটি দলিল রেজিস্ট্রি করেন এবং সেই ভুলের কারণে কারো ক্ষতি হয়, তাহলে তার কী শাস্তি হতে পারে?
answer: রেজিস্ট্রেশন আইন, ১৯০৮ এর ধারা ৮১ অনুযায়ী, যদি কোনো রেজিস্ট্রি অফিসার অথবা তার অফিসে কর্মরত কেউ ইচ্ছাকৃতভাবে কোনো দলিলের ভুল করে অনুমোদন, নকল, অনুবাদ বা রেজিস্ট্রি করেন এবং সেই ভুলের কারণে অন্য কারো ক্ষতি হয় (পেনাল কোডে যেভাবে ক্ষতির সংজ্ঞা দেওয়া হয়েছে) , তাহলে তাকে ৭ বছর পর্যন্ত কারাদণ্ড, জরিমানা অথবা উভয়দণ্ড হতে পারে। এখানে ক্ষতির কারণ হওয়ার ইচ্ছা অথবা ক্ষতির সম্ভাবনা গুরুত্বপূর্ণ।

question: I saw someone offering to help me with registration for a fee. They appeared on a publicly displayed list of touts. What could happen to them?
answer: According to Section 82A of The Registration Act, 1908, if a person who is listed as a tout continues to act as a tout, they can be punished with imprisonment for up to three months, fined up to 500 taka, or both. This applies specifically to individuals whose names are already on the list of touts published under the Act.

answer: A 'tout' is someone who solicits or advertises services related to registration, often for a fee, potentially misleading people. Section 82A of The Registration Act, 1908 addresses individuals who are already identified as touts and have their names published. answer: রেজিস্ট্রেশন আইন, ১৯০৮ এর ধারা ৮২এ অনুযায়ী, যদি কোনো ব্যক্তির নাম ইতিমধ্যেই দালালদের তালিকায় তালিকাভুক্ত করা হয়ে থাকে এবং সেই ব্যক্তি দালাল হিসেবে কাজ চালিয়ে যায়, তাহলে তাকে সর্বোচ্চ তিন মাস পর্যন্ত কারাদণ্ড, ৫০০ টাকা পর্যন্ত জরিমানা অথবা এই দুইই হতে পারে।

question: What happens if I lie to a government official while dealing with property registration, and is there a specific punishment?
answer: Section 82 of The Registration Act, 1908 states that if you intentionally make a false statement, whether you swear an oath or not, to any government official involved in property registration proceedings or inquiries, you can be punished with imprisonment for up to seven years, or fined, or both. This applies even if the statement isn't officially recorded.
law_reference: The Registration Act, 1908, Part XIV, Section 82

82. Whoever-
 
 
(a) intentionally makes any false statement, whether on oath or not, and whether it has been recorded or not, before any officer acting in execution of this Act, in any proceeding or enquiry under this Act; or
 
 
(b) intentionally delivers to a registering officer, in any proceeding under section 19 or section 21, a false copy or translation of a document or a false copy of a map or plan; or
 
 
(c) falsely personates another, and in such assumed character presents any document, or makes any admission or statement, or causes any summons or commission to be issued, or does any other act in any proceeding or enquiry under this Act; or
 
 
(d) abets anything made punishable by this Act;
 
 
shall be punishable with imprisonment for a term which may extend to seven years, or with fine or with both.

answer: According to Section 82 of The Registration Act, 1908, if you intentionally give a registering officer a false copy or translation of a document, or a false copy of a map or plan, during proceedings under sections 19 or 21, you are liable to be punished with imprisonment for a term that can extend to seven years, or a fine, or both.

question: যদি আমি মিথ্যা পরিচয়ে কোনো নথি জমা দেই বা নিবন্ধনের জন্য মিথ্যা বক্তব্য দেই, তাহলে কী শাস্তি হতে পারে? (Jodi ami mithya porichoy-e kono nothi joma dei ba nibhandoner jonno mithya bokbhabi dei, tahole ki shashti hote pare?)
answer: ধারা ৮২ অনুযায়ী, যদি আপনি মিথ্যা পরিচয়ে কোনো নথি জমা দেন, অথবা নিবন্ধনের জন্য মিথ্যা বক্তব্য দেন, তাহলে আপনাকে সর্বোচ্চ সাত বছর পর্যন্ত কারাদণ্ড, অথবা জরিমানা, অথবা দুটোই হতে পারে। যদি আপনি অন্য কারো ছদ্মবেশ ধারণ করে কোনো কাজ করেন, যেমন নকল কাগজপত্র উপস্থাপন করা বা মিথ্যা заявление দেওয়া, অথবা আদালতের সমন জারি করা, সেক্ষেত্রেও একই শাস্তি প্রযোজ্য হবে। (Dhara 82 onusharone, jodi ami mithya porichoy-e kono nothi joma den, athoba nibhandoner jonno mithya bokbhabi dei, tahole ami mokshyo sato bochor porjonto karadondo, athoba jarina, athoba duitoi hote pare. question: If I suspect a registrar is committing fraud related to property registration, who can authorize the legal proceedings against them?
answer: According to Section 83 of The Registration Act, 1908, a prosecution against a registering officer (or someone committing an offence related to registration) can be commenced with the permission of the Inspector-General, the Registrar, or the Sub-Registrar. This means they have the authority to allow the legal process to begin in the area where the offence took place.
law_reference: The Registration Act, 1908, Part XIV, Section 83

(1) A prosecution for any offence under this Act coming to the knowledge of a registering officer in his official capacity may be commenced by or with the permission of the Inspector-General, the Registrar or the Sub-Registrar, in whose territories, district or sub-district, as the case may be, the offence has been committed.
 
 
(2) Save as provided in section 80F, offences punishable under this Act shall be triable by any Court or officer exercising powers not less than those of a Magistrate of the second class.

question: আমি যদি কোনো নিবন্ধন কর্মকর্তার বিরুদ্ধে অপরাধের অভিযোগ পাই, তাহলে কে এই বিষয়ে আইনি পদক্ষেপ নিতে পারবে?

question: What does it mean for a registering officer to be considered a 'public servant' under the law?
answer: Section 84(1) of The Registration Act, 1908 states that a registering officer appointed under this Act is legally considered a public servant. This means they are subject to the laws and regulations that apply to public servants, including those found in the Penal Code. Basically, they have certain responsibilities and are accountable in a similar way to other government officials.
law_reference: The Registration Act, 1908, Part XIV, Section 84

question: If a registering officer asks me for information, am I legally obligated to provide it?
answer: Yes, Section 84(2) of The Registration Act, 1908 makes it legally binding for everyone to furnish information to a registering officer if they are asked to do so. You cannot refuse to provide this information without a legal reason.

question: My property documents were registered at a local registration office, but I'm moving abroad. What happens to them if I don't collect them after a few years?
answer: According to Section 85 of The Registration Act, 1908, if your property documents (or any other documents besides wills) remain unclaimed at a registration office for more than two years, the office has the authority to destroy them. It's highly recommended you arrange for someone to collect them regularly or request the office to transfer them to your current address to avoid this.
law_reference: The Registration Act, 1908, Part XV, Section 85
input_context: 85. Documents (other than wills) remaining unclaimed in any registration office for a period exceeding two years may be destroyed.

question: I heard that the registration office can get rid of old documents. Can they just throw away any document?
answer: No, not just any document. Section 85 of The Registration Act, 1908 specifies that only documents (excluding wills) that remain unclaimed in a registration office for more than two years can be destroyed. The office has to wait for that two-year period to pass before they can consider destroying them.
law_reference: The Registration Act, 1908, Part XV, Section 85

question: আমার জমির কাগজপত্র রেজিস্ট্রেশন অফিসে unclaimed পড়ে আছে। দুই বছরের বেশি সময় পর সেগুলো কী হতে পারে? (Amar jomir kaporoncho registration office-e unclaimed pore ache. Dhwai bochor'er beshi somoy por sheguli ki hote pare?)
answer: রেজিস্ট্রেশন আইন, ১৯০৮ এর ৮৫ নং ধারা অনুযায়ী, যদি আপনার জমির কাগজপত্র (wills ছাড়া) রেজিস্ট্রেশন অফিসে দুই বছরের বেশি সময় ধরে unclaimed থাকে, তাহলে অফিস কর্তৃপক্ষ সেগুলো ধ্বংস করতে পারে। আপনার কাগজপত্রগুলো সুরক্ষিত রাখতে, নিয়মিতভাবে সংগ্রহ করার ব্যবস্থা করুন অথবা অফিসের কাছে আপনার বর্তমান ঠিকানায় কাগজপত্র স্থানান্তর করার অনুরোধ করুন। (Registration Ain, 1908 er 85 no dhara onushare, jodi amar jomir kaporoncho registration office-e dhwai bochor'er beshi somoy dhore unclaimed thake, tahole office okottho sheguli hunshto korte pare. Amar kaporoncho gorjjo tokhon sokorjo rakhne, nithirmate sokorjjo korar bhabna korun ebong office-er kadhe amar bortoman thikana-e kaporoncho spostaharon korar orod korun.)

question: If I believe a registering officer made a mistake in their job, can I sue them for it?
answer: No, you generally cannot. Section 86 of The Registration Act, 1908, states that a registering officer is not liable to be sued for anything they do or don't do while acting in good faith and performing their official duties.  'Good faith' means they genuinely believed they were doing the right thing according to the law. However, this doesn't mean they are immune to all scrutiny; there may be other avenues to address grievances.
law_reference: The Registration Act, 1908, Part XV, Section 86
input_context: 86. No registering officer shall be liable to any suit claim or demand by reason of anything in good faith done or refused in his official capacity.

question: What does 'acting in good faith' mean for a registering officer?
answer: Section 86 of The Registration Act, 1908, protects registering officers when they’re acting 'in good faith.' This means they honestly believe their actions were correct and lawful at the time they performed their duties.  It doesn’t mean they were perfect, but rather that they didn’t act with malice or intentionally break the law.  It's a crucial protection to allow them to perform their duties without constant fear of legal action.
law_reference: The Registration Act, 1908, Part XV, Section 86

question: রেজিস্ট্রি অফিসার যদি ভুল করে, তাহলে কি তার বিরুদ্ধে মামলা করা যাবে?
answer: না, সাধারণত পারবেন না। রেজিস্ট্রেশন আইন, ১৯০৮ এর ৮৬ ধারা অনুযায়ী, একজন রেজিস্ট্রি অফিসার যদি সৎ উদ্দেশ্যে এবং তার দাপ্তরিক দায়িত্ব পালনকালে কোনো কাজ করেন বা না করেন, তবে তার বিরুদ্ধে মামলা করা যাবে না। 'সৎ উদ্দেশ্যে' বলতে বোঝায় তিনি বিশ্বাস করতেন যে তিনি আইন অনুযায়ী সঠিক কাজটি করছেন। তবে এর মানে এই নয় যে তিনি সব ধরনের জবাবদিহিতা থেকে মুক্ত; অভিযোগ জানানোর অন্যান্য উপায় থাকতে পারে।

question: If it turns out the registering officer wasn't appointed correctly, can the registration still be valid?
answer: Section 87(1) of The Registration Act, 1908 states that even if there was a mistake in how a registering officer was appointed or in the process they followed, the registration itself won't be considered invalid, as long as they acted in good faith.  Essentially, a technical error in appointment doesn’t automatically make the registration void.
law_reference: The Registration Act, 1908, Part XV, Section 87

question: My cousin presented a document for registration without proper authorization. Can the registration be challenged simply because of that?
answer: According to Section 87(2) of The Registration Act, 1908, if someone presents a document for registration without having the proper authority to do so, that issue alone isn't enough to invalidate the registration. question: I understand that some government officials don't need to be physically present or sign documents when registering them. Who exactly are these officials?
answer: Section 88 of The Registration Act, 1908 states that certain government officers, including the Administrator-General of Bangladesh, Official Trustees, Official Assignees, Receivers, and Registrars of the Supreme Court, are exempt from needing to appear in person or sign documents when registering instruments they've executed in their official capacity. This simplifies the registration process for these individuals.
law_reference: The Registration Act, 1908, Part XV, Section 88
input_context:
88. (1) Notwithstanding anything herein contained, it shall not be necessary for any officer of Government, or for the Administrator-General of Bangladesh or for any Official Trustee or Official Assignee, or for the Receiver or Registrar of the Supreme Court, to appear in person or by agent at any registration office in any proceeding connected with the registration of any instrument executed by him in his official capacity, or to sign as provided in section 58.
 
 
(2) Where any instrument is so executed, the registering officer to whom such instrument is presented for registration may, if he thinks fit, refer to any Secretary to Government or to such officer of Government, Administrator-Genera, Official Trustee, Official Assignee, Receiver or Registrar, as the case may be, for information respecting the same, and, on being satisfied of the execution thereof, shall register the instrument.

question: If a government official executes a document officially, does the Registering Officer have to take extra steps to verify it?
answer: Yes, Section 88(2) states that when a document is executed by one of the specified government officials (like the Administrator-General), the Registering Officer can, if they feel it’s necessary, consult with a Secretary to Government or other relevant officials to get information about the document.  Ultimately, if the Registering Officer is satisfied with the execution, they are obligated to register the instrument.

question: I took out a loan for land improvement. Does the government need a copy of the order approving that loan?
answer: Yes, according to Section 89 of the Registration Act, 1908, if you took out a loan under the Land Improvement Loans Act, 1883, the officer who granted the loan must send a copy of their order to the registering officer in the area where the land is located. This copy will be filed in the registering officer’s Book No. 1. This ensures a record of the loan is kept with the registration office.
law_reference: The Registration Act, 1908, Part XV, Section 89
input_context:
89. (1) Every officer granting a loan under the Land Improvement Loans Act, 1883, shall send a copy of his order to the registering officer within the local limits of whose jurisdiction the whole or any part of the land to be improved or of the land to be granted as collateral security, is situate, and such registering officer shall file the copy in his Book No. 1.
 
 
(2) Every Court granting a certificate of sale of immovable property under the Code of Civil Procedure, 1908, shall send a copy of such certificate to the registering officer within the local limits of whose jurisdiction whole or any part of the immoveable property comprised in such certificate is situate, and such officer shall file the copy in his Book No. 1.
 
 
(3) Every officer and every Co-operative Society granting any such loan as is referred to in clause (x) of sub-section (2) of section 17 shall send a copy of any instrument whereby immoveable property is mortgaged for the purpose of securing the repayment of the loan, and if any such property is mortgaged for the same purpose in the order granting the loan, a copy also of that order, to the registering officer within the local limits of whose jurisdiction the whole or any part of the property so mortgaged is situate, and such registering officer shall file the copy or copies, as the case may be, in his Book No. 1.
 
 
(4) Every Revenue-officer granting a certificate of sale to the purchaser of immoveable property sold by public auction shall send a copy of the certificate to the registering officer within the local limits of whose jurisdiction the whole or any part of the property comprised in the certificate is situate, and such officer shall file the copy in his Book No. 1.

question: আমার একটি জমি বন্ধক রাখা হয়েছে একটি কৃষি ঋণ পাওয়ার জন্য। এই তথ্য কি নিবন্ধন অফিসে জানাতে হবে?
answer: হ্যাঁ, নিবন্ধন আইন, ১৯০৮ এর ধারা ৮৯ অনুসারে, যদি আপনি একটি কৃষি ঋণ পাওয়ার জন্য জমি বন্ধক রাখেন, তাহলে ঋণ প্রদানকারী কর্মকর্তা বা সমবায় সমিতি জমি বন্ধকের জন্য ব্যবহৃত চুক্তিপত্রের একটি কপি স্থানীয় নিবন্ধন অফিসে পাঠাতে বাধ্য। এই কপি নিবন্ধন অফিসারের বই নং ১-এ জমা রাখা হবে।

question: I understand that some documents don't need to be registered. Does this include records created during land revenue settlements?
answer: Yes, according to Section 90 of The Registration Act, 1908, documents issued, received, or attested by officers involved in land revenue settlements, and which are part of the settlement records, do not need to be registered. This exemption applies to the records made during the process of land revenue settlement.
law_reference: The Registration Act, 1908, Part XV, Section 90

90. (1) Nothing contained in this Act shall be deemed to require, or to have at any time required, the registration of any of the following documents or maps, namely:-
 
 
(a) documents issued, received or attested by any officer engaged in making a settlement or revision of settlement of land-revenue, and which form part of the records of such settlement; or
 
 
(b) documents and maps issued, received or authenticated by any officer engaged on behalf of Government in making or revising the survey of any land, and which form part of the record of such survey; or
 
 
(c) documents which, under any law for the time being in force, are filed periodically in any revenue-office by patwaries or other officers charged with the preparation of village-records; or
 
 
(d) sanads, inam title-deeds and other documents purporting to be or to evidence grants or assignments by Government of land or of any interest in land;
 
 
(2) All such documents and maps shall, for the purposes of sections 48 and 49, be deemed to have been and to be registered in accordance with the provisions of this Act.

question: আমি ভূমি সরকারের কাছ থেকে জমির দলিল পেয়েছি, এটা কি রেজিস্ট্রেশন করতে হবে?

question: আমি কিভাবে জমির নথিপত্র দেখতে ও নকল নিতে পারি?

question: Who may appoint an Inspector-General of Registration and can the same officer simultaneously hold any other post?
answer: The Government of Bangladesh is empowered to appoint the Inspector-General of Registration (Section 3).  The proviso to that section allows the Government to direct that the powers and duties of the Inspector-General may instead be exercised by some other officer(s) within specified local limits.  Section 3(2) further clarifies that any Inspector-General may, at the same time, hold any other office in the service of the Republic.

(2) Any Inspector-General may hold simultaneously any other office in the service of the Republic.

question: How are districts and sub-districts created for the purposes of this Act, and how are alterations in their limits made public?
answer: Section 5(1) empowers the Government to form districts and sub-districts and to prescribe or alter their limits.  Every such formation or alteration must be notified in the official Gazette (Section 5(2)), and the alteration takes effect on the day mentioned in the notification (Section 5(3)).

question: What happens when a Sub-Registrar’s office is amalgamated with that of the Registrar, and must duplicate sets of books be maintained?

question: What mandatory particulars must be included in (and attached to) an instrument of sale of immovable property before the Registering Officer can register it?

question: What is the time-limit for presenting a contract for sale of immovable property for registration, and what happens if a contract executed before Section 17A came into force is not registered?
answer: Section 17A(2) requires every contract for sale to be presented within thirty days from its execution. answer: Under Section 23A, a document once accepted and registered from a person not duly empowered can be re-registered within four months after the party first learns the registration is invalid. However, for simple delay beyond three months, you must instead seek Registrar’s condonation under Section 25(1) within four months of execution plus fine.

answer: Since you reside outside Bangladesh, the power-of-attorney must be executed before and authenticated by a Notary Public, any Court, Judge, Magistrate, Bangladesh Consul or Vice-Consul, or a representative of the Government (Section 33(1)(c)). question: I gifted my agricultural land to my son by a heba-bil-ewaz. How much registration fee will I pay regardless of the market value?

question: A will was deposited in 2015 but no registration or opening steps were ever taken. Can it now be destroyed, and what safeguards exist?
answer: Yes. Section 46A empowers destruction after a prescribed procedure: every three years the Registrar sends notice to the depositor/nominee; if satisfied the testator is dead, a six-month notice is issued to the executor/beneficiaries; if still unclaimed, the will can be destroyed under the Destruction of Records Act, 1917, but registration can still be effected on request until actual destruction.

question: My document is written in French and the Sub-Registrar says he cannot register it. What exactly must accompany the deed to enable registration?

question: আমার মা তার উইলটি ২০১৮ সালে সিলগালা খামে জমা দিয়েছেন। তিনি এখনও জীবিত। আমি কি খামটি দেখতে পারব?
answer: না। ধারা ৪৪ অনুযায়ী জীবিত উইলকারীর অনুমতি ছাড়া সিলগালা খামটি খোলা যাবে না। তিনি নিজে বা তার প্রকৃত প্রতিনিধি আবেদন করলে খাম ফেরত দেওয়া যেতে পারে, তবে অন্য কেউ দেখতে পারবে না।
law_reference: The Registration Act, 1908, ধারা ৪৪

question: আমার বাবা জেলে আছেন। তিনি একটি বায়না দলিলে সই করেছেন। তাকে রেজিস্ট্রি অফিসে হাজির করা হবে কি?
answer: ধারা ৩৮(১)(বি) অনুযায়ী দেহাশ্রয় বা কারাগারে থাকা ব্যক্তিকে রেজিস্ট্রি অফিসে হাজির হতে হয় না। রেজিস্ট্রি কর্মকর্তা জেলখানায় গিয়ে পরীক্ষা করবেন বা কমিশন ইস্যু করবেন (৩৮(২))।

question: আমি একটি হেবা দলিল দাখিল করেছি। নির্ধারিত ফি কত হবে যদি সম্পত্তির মূল্য ৩ লক্ষ টাকা হয় এবং গ্রহীতা আমার সন্তান?
answer: ধারা ৭৮এ(বি) অনুসারে পিতা-মাতা ও সন্তানের মধ্যে হেবায় নির্ধারিত ফি সম্পত্তির মূল্য নির্বিশেষে মাত্র ১০০ টাকা।

question: আমি ভাগ দলিলের জন্য রেজিস্ট্রি ফি জানতে চাই; সম্পত্তির মূল্য ৪৫ লক্ষ টাকা।

question: আমার দলিলে কিছু শব্দ মুছে ফেলা হয়েছে। সাব-রেজিস্ট্রার কি রেজিস্ট্রেশন করতে পারবেন?
answer: ধারা ২০(১) অনুযায়ী মুছে ফেলা অংশে সই বা ইনিশিয়াল না থাকলে সাব-রেজিস্ট্রার রেজিস্ট্রেশন করতে পারেন না। সই/ইনিশিয়াল দিয়ে মুছে ফেলা অংশটি স্বীকৃত হলে তবে রেজিস্ট্রেশন সম্ভব।

question: আমি ঢাকা শহরের একটি ফ্ল্যাট বিক্রি করছি। দলিলে সম্পত্তি বর্ণনায় কী কী দিতে হবে?

law_reference: The Registration Act, 1908, ধারা ২১(২)

21. (1) No non-testamentary document relating to immoveable property shall be accepted for registration unless it contains a description of such property sufficient to identify the same.

question: আমি একই দলিলে দুই জেলার জমি দিয়েছি। রেজিস্ট্রি করার পর কী কী কপি পাঠাতে হবে?

question: আমার দলিলে কিছু শব্দ ভুল লেখা হয়েছে। সাব-রেজিস্ট্রার ভুল সংশোধন করতে পারবেন কি?

question: আমি একটি বায়না দলিলে সই করেছি কিন্তু রেজিস্ট্রি করিনি। এখন ক্রেতা আমার বিরুদ্ধে মামলা করেছে। দলিলটি কি আদালতে গ্রহণযোগ্য হবে?

law_reference: The Registration Act, 1908, ধারা ৪৯

question: আমি একটি বাড়ি বিক্রি করেছি কিন্তু দলিলে দাম কম দেখিয়েছি। রেজিস্ট্রি অফিসার কী করতে পারেন?

question: আমার নাম একটি তাউট তালিকায় অন্তর্ভুক্ত করা হয়েছে। আমি কীভাবে আপত্তি জানাতে পারি?

question: আমি একটি বাড়ি ভাড়া দিয়েছি ৩ বছরের জন্য। এই লিজ দলিল রেজিস্ট্রি বাধ্যতামূলক কি না?
answer: ধারা ১৭(১)(ঘ) অনুসারে এক বছরের অধিক মেয়াদের বা বার্ষিক ভাড়া সংরক্ষিত লিজ রেজিস্ট্রি বাধ্যতামূলক। ৩ বছরের লিজ তাই নিবন্ধন করতে হবে, যদি না সরকার বিশেষ অব্যাহতি দিয়েছে (১৭(১) প্রভিজো)।
law_reference: The Registration Act, 1908, ধারা ১৭(১)(ঘ)
input_context:
17. (1) The following documents shall be registered, if the property to which they relate is situate in a district in which, and if they have been executed on or after the date on which, this Act came or comes into force, namely:-
 
 
(a) instruments of gift of immoveable property;
 
 
(aa) declaration of heba under the Muslim Personal Law (Shariat);
 
 
(aaa) declaration of gift under the Hindu, Christian and Buddhist Personal Law;
 
 
(b) other non-testamentary instruments which purport or operate to create, declare, assign, limit or extinguish, whether in present or in future, any right, title or interest, whether vested or contingent, to or in immoveable property;
 
 
Explanation − In the case of an assignment of a mortgage the consideration for the deed of assignment shall be deemed to be the value for registration.
 
 
(c) Non-testamentary instruments (other than the acknowledge-ment of a receipt or payment made in respect of any transaction to which an instrument registered under clause (o) relates) which acknowledge the receipt or payment of any consideration on account of the creation, declaration, assignment, limitation or extinction of any such right, title or interest; and
 
 
(cc) instrument of mortgage referred to in section 59 of the Transfer of Property Act, 1882;
 
 
(d) leases of immoveable property from year to year, or for any term exceeding one year, or reserving a yearly rent;
 
 
(e) non-testamentary instruments transferring or assigning any decree or order of a Court or any award when such decree or order or award purports or operates to create, declare, assign, limit or extinguish, whether in present or in future, any right, title or interest, whether vested or contingent, to or in immoveable property;
 
 
(f) instrument of partition of immovable property effected by persons upon inheritance according to their respective personal laws;
 
 
(g) instrument of sale in pursuance of an order of the Court under section 96 of the State Acquisition and Tenancy Act, 1950:
 
 
Provided that the Government may, by order published in the official Gazette, exempt from the operation of this sub-section any leases executed in any district, or part of a district, the terms granted by which do not exceed five years and the annual rents reserved by which do not exceed fifty taka.
 
 
(2) Nothing in clauses (b) and (c) of sub-section (1) applies to-
 
 
(i) any composition deed; or
 
 
(ii) any instrument relating to shares in a Joint Stock Company, notwithstanding that the assets of such Company consist in whole or in part of immoveable property; or
 
 
(iii) any debenture issued by any such Company and not creating, declaring, assigning, limiting or extinguishing any right, title or interest, to or in immoveable property except in so far as it entitles the holder to the security afforded by a registered instrument whereby the Company has mortgaged, conveyed or otherwise transferred the whole or part of its immoveable property or any interest therein to trustees upon trust for the benefit of the holders of such debentures; or
 
 
(iv) any endorsement upon or transfer of any debenture issued by any such Company; or
 
 
(v) any document not itself creating, declaring, assigning, limiting or extinguishing any right, title or interest to or in immoveable property, but merely creating a right to obtain another document which will, when executed, create, declare, assign, limit or extinguish any such right, title or interest; or
 
 
(vi) any decree or order of a Court except a decree or order expressed to be made on a compromise and comprising immoveable property other than that which is the subject-matter of the suit or proceeding; or
 
 
(vii) any grant of immoveable property by the Government; or
 
 
(viii) any instrument of partition made by a Revenue-officer; or
 
 
(ix) any order granting a loan or instrument of collateral security granted under the Land Improvement Act, 1871, or the Land Improvement Loans Act, 1883; or
 
 
(x) any order granting a loan under the Agriculturists' Loans Act, 1884, the Bangladesh Krishi Bank Order, 1973 or under any other law for the time being in force relating to the advancement of loans for agricultural purposes, or any instrument under which a loan is granted by a co-operative society for any such purpose, or any instrument made for securing the repayment of a loan so granted; or
 
 
(xi) any endorsement on a mortgage-deed acknowledging the payment of the whole or any part of the mortgage-money, and any other receipt for payment of money due under a mortgage; or
 
 
(xii) any certificate of sale granted to the purchaser of any property sold by public auction by a Civil or Revenue-officer; or
 
 
(xiii)any counter-part of a lease, where the lease corresponding thereto has itself been registered.
 
 
(3) Authorities to adopt a son, executed after the first day of January 1872, and not conferred by a will, shall also be registered.

question: আমি ২০২৩ সালের অক্টোবরে একটি বায়না দলিলে সই করেছি, কিন্তু এখনো রেজিস্ট্রি করিনি। আমি কি এটি এখনও রেজিস্ট্রি করতে পারব, নাকি দলিলটি বাতিল হয়ে গেছে?
answer: ধারা ১৭-এ এবং ১৭-বি অনুযায়ী, যদি বায়না দলিল ধারা ১৭-এ কার্যকর হওয়ার আগে সই হয়ে থাকে, তবে ১৭-এ কার্যকর হওয়ার তারিখ থেকে ছয় মাসের মধ্যে সেটি রেজিস্ট্রি করা যাবে। ছয় মাস পার হয়ে গেলে আপনি পরবর্তী ছয় মাসের মধ্যে specific performance-এর মামলা করতে পারবেন; না হলে দলিলটি বাতিল হয়ে যাবে।

(2) The provision of sub-section (1) shall not apply to any contract for sale of immovable property on the basis of which a suit has been instituted in a civil court before coming into force of section 17A.
